questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with SLE complicated by nephropathy, hemolytic anemia, and pleuritis. Her disease is well controlled on therapy. She recently discovered that she is pregnant and presents today for prenatal counseling. She specifically is concerned about the effect her disease may have on the infant. You tell her that the most common cardiac complication in children born to mothers with SLE is:
questions.solution:
Congenital atrioventricular block in the setting of a structurally normal heart has been seen in children born to mothers with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

SLE can cause sterile endocarditis in adults, but it is not common in children of mothers with SLE. Similarly, early-onset coronary artery disease, pulmonary hypertension, and occasionally cardiomyopathy is described in SLE patients but not in their children just after birth.

Congenital AV block may be observed in complex congenital cardiac anomalies, such as transposition of the great arteries, ostium primum ASDs, VSDs, endocardial cushion defects, and some single-ventricle defects. Congenital AV block in the setting of a structurally normal heart has been seen in children born to mothers with SLE and other autoimmune diseases

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1882

questions.text: The most common indication for pancreas transplant is
questions.solution:
Pancreas transplant is the most common treatment for type 1 diabetes with diabetic neuropathy. It can help to improve blood sugar control and reduce the risk of complications from diabetes, such as heart disease, stroke, kidney failure, and blindness.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1623

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with new onset right lower quadrant pain, and you palpate enlarged, tender right adnexa. Which of the following sonographic characteristics of the cyst in this patient suggests the need for surgical exploration now instead of observation for one menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
USG features of malignant ovarian tumour:

  • Hypoechoic solid area within the mass (highly echogenic solid areas due to fat or calcification are typical of dermoids).
  • Thick (more than 3 mm) nodular septations / papillary vegetations
  • Size of mass greater than 7 cm, although very large but simple cysts are usually benign cystadenomas.
  • Central rather than peripheral vascularity.
  • RI less than 0.6. RI greater than 0.8 is suggestive of benign disease but there is an indeterminate range of 0.6 - 0.8.

Presence of papillary vegetation is suggestive of malignancy and hence is an indication for laparotomy.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 6th Edition, Page no. 1083

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines should not be frozen?
questions.solution:
• OPV, BCG and Measles are stable from freezing. Rest all other vaccines are sensitive to freezing and must not be frozen.

Reference: IAP guidebook on immunization, 3rd edition, page no 52

questions.text: A 40 year old patient came with complaints of spikes of fever and difficulty in breathing. TEE shows multiple vegetations on surface of heart valves. Blood culture showed growth of Burkholderia cepacia. Which of the following is first line management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Burkholderia cepacia organisms are intrinsically resistant to many antibiotics, rendering empiric treatment difficult.

Therefore, treatment must be tailored according to sensitivities.

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX), meropenem, and minocycline are the most active agents in vitro and may be started as first-line agents.

Some strains are susceptible to third-generation ureidopenicillins, advanced cephalosporins, and fluoroquinolones, and these agents may be used against isolates known to be susceptible.

Newer antibiotics such as ceftolozane/ tazobactam and ceftazidime/avibactam show good activity against MDR strains in vitro.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1290

questions.text: A 25 year old male patient presented to urology OPD with complain of dragging type of discomfort in left side of testes that was worse on standing at the end of day. When examined in the erect posture, the scrotum on the affected side hangs lower than normal. The lesion is visible and palpable at rest. What is the grade of this lesion?
questions.solution:
The following classification of varicocele is useful in clinical practice:

Subclinical: Not palpable or visible at rest or during a Valsalva maneuver, but can be shown by special tests (Doppler ultrasound studies).

Grade 1: Palpable during Valsalva maneuver, but not otherwise.

Grade 2: Palpable at rest, but not visible.

Grade 3: Visible and palpable at rest.

The patient in this question has a grade 3 varicocele, as the lesion is visible and palpable at rest.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1564

questions.text: In a case of secondary amenorrhea who fails to get withdrawal bleeding after taking Estrogen and Progesterone, the fault lies at the level of:
questions.solution:
Estrogen-progesterone challenge test

Procedure: Ethinyl estradiol (.02 mg) or conjugated equine estrogen (1.25 mg) is given daily for 25 days. MDPA 10 mg daily is added from day 15 to 25 (Alternatively estrogen is given for 21 days and progesterone is added in last 5 days).

If a woman fails to get withdrawal bleeding after taking estrogen and progesterone, it means that the endometrium is not responsive to hormones. This can be caused by a defect in the endometrium itself, or by a defect in the outflow tract.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 5th Edition, Page no. 447

questions.text: Mixed venous oxygen saturation is high in which type of shock?
questions.solution:
Distributive shock is characterized by a high mixed venous oxygen saturation. This is due to the fact that blood is shunted away from the tissues and towards the vital organs.

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient is known case of Hypertension and COPD. He suddenly develops breathlessness at rest, chest pain and palpitation. On examination His BP was 80/60 mmHg, PR=142/min. ECG shown below. D-dimer positive. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case Patient had acute onset breathlessness and hemodynamically unstable inform of the Hypotension and Tachycardia.

ECG suggest Sinus Tachycardia and S1Q3T3 pattern. D-dimer is positive.

So, the diagnosis is Acute pulmonary Embolism in this patient.

questions.text: Preconceptional intake of which of the following results in decrease in incidence of neural tube defect?
questions.solution:
• Therapeutic dose of folic acid (to be given in females with previous history of baby with NTD) - 4 mg.
  • Prophylactic dose of folic acid = 0.4 mg i.e., 400 mg
  • Duration: It should be started 1 month before conception and continued till 3 months of pregnancy.

Note: Women with insulin dependent diabetes mellitus and those with seizure disorders treated by valproic acid and carbamazepine are also at greater risk for NTD's and should be given therapeutic dose of folic acid i.e., 4 mg.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 24th Edition, Page no 197

questions.text: When you are suspecting a child of having progressive spinal muscular atrophy, which of the following finding you do not expect to be present?
questions.solution:
• Spinal muscular atrophy is classified into three forms: infantile, late infantile and juvenile. The specific gene defect (autosomal recessive inheritance) is localized to chromosome 5, which in the defective state fails to suppress the normal pre-programmed neuronal cell death at birth.
  • The characteristic features are fasciculations seen best in the resting tongue, fibrillation potentials in EMG and denervation pattern on a muscle biopsy.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, page no 2997

questions.text: A 30 year female has low serum calcium and phosphate with elevated parathormone. Diagnosis is-
questions.solution:
Vitamin D deficiency will have: -

  1. Low calcium
  2. Low phosphate
  3. High alkaline phosphatase
  4. High parathormone level (secondary hyperparathyroidism)

About other options

In primary hyperparathyroidism

  1. High calcium
  2. Low phosphate
  3. High alkaline phosphatase
  4. High parathormone level

In osteoporosis all these parameters are normal.

In Paget's disease calcium and phosphate levels are normal. Serum alkaline phosphatase is raised.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition, Page no 302

questions.text:
Identify the true and false about assessing the area of a burn
a) The patient's foot is 1% TBSA and is a useful guide in small burns
b) The Lund and Browder chart is useful in larger burns
c) The 'rule of nines' is adequate for a first approximation only
d) An infant's head is proportionally larger than an adult's and this adjustment is represented on the modified Lund and Browder chart for children, where at birth the head represents 18% and the lower limbs 13.5% each
questions.solution:
The body proportions of children necessitate adjustment of the above-mentioned scales. An infant's head is proportionally larger than an adult's and this adjustment is represented on the modified Lund and Browder chart for children, where at birth the head represents 18% and the lower limbs 13.5% each. For each year 1% is subtracted from the head, with 0.5% being added to each lower limb until the age of 10, when the body proportions are roughly equivalent to those of an adult.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 668

choices.text: Pain out of proportion to that expected
Pain on active stretching of the muscles in the affected compartment
Paralysis, paraesthesia, pallor and pulselessness generally occur late

questions.text: All are the symptoms and signs of compartment syndrome except
questions.solution:
Compartment syndrome is a serious medical condition that occurs when pressure within a closed anatomical compartment (such as a muscle compartment) becomes elevated to the point that it impairs blood flow and damages the tissues within that compartment. The common signs and symptoms of compartment syndrome include:

  • A) Pain out of proportion to that expected: This is one of the hallmark symptoms of compartment syndrome. The pain is typically severe and disproportionate to the initial injury or trauma.
  • B) Pain that is increasing: The pain tends to worsen over time, and it may not be relieved by rest or pain medication. This increasing pain is indicative of compartment syndrome.
  • C) Pain on active stretching of the muscles in the affected compartment: This statement is incorrect. In compartment syndrome, pain is typically aggravated by passive stretching of the muscles, not active stretching. Passive stretching is when a healthcare provider or someone else stretches the muscles, and the patient experiences severe pain when this is done.
  • D) Paralysis, paraesthesia, pallor, and pulselessness generally occur late: These are late signs of compartment syndrome and indicate advanced and severe stages of the condition. When the pressure within the compartment is significantly elevated, it can lead to nerve damage, reduced blood flow, and tissue death. These late signs are indicative of severe and advanced compartment syndrome.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 326

questions.text: What is the most common electrolyte abnormality in hospitalized patient?
questions.solution:
Hyponatremia, which is defined as a plasma Na concentration <135 mEq/L, is a very common disorder, occurring in up to 22% of hospitalized patients.

This disorder is almost always the result of an increase in circulating AVP and/or increased renal sensitivity to AVP, combined with an intake of free water; a notable exception is hyponatremia due to low solute intake.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 342

choices.text: Autosomal recessive inherited disease due to mutations of the APC gene
More than 100 colonic adenomas are diagnostic
Prophylactic surgery is indicated to prevent colorectal cancer
Polyps and malignant tumours can develop particularly around the duodenal ampulla

questions.text: All are true about FAP (Familial adenomatous polyposis) EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant inherited disease due to mutations of the APC gene. It is characterized by the development of multiple colonic adenomas, which can lead to colorectal cancer.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 1356

questions.text: A 63 year old chronic bidi smoker presenting with polyuria, pain in abdomen, nausea, vomiting and altered sensorium was found to have Bronchogenic carcinoma. The electrolyte abnormalities seen in him?
questions.solution:
Systemic symptoms of anorexia, cachexia, weight loss (seen in 30% of patients), fever, and suppressed immunity are paraneoplastic syndromes of unknown etiology or at least not well defined.

Weight loss >10% of total body weight is considered a bad prognostic sign.

Endocrine syndromes are seen in 12% of patients; hypercalcemia resulting from ectopic production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) or, more commonly, PTH-related peptide is the most common life-threatening metabolic complication of malignancy, primarily occurring with squamous cell carcinomas of the lung.

Clinical symptoms include nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation, polyuria, thirst, and altered mental status.

Hyponatremia may be caused by the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) or possibly atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP).

Ectopic secretion of ACTH by SCLC and pulmonary carcinoids usually results in additional electrolyte disturbances, especially hypokalemia, rather than the changes in body habitus that occur in Cushing's syndrome from a pituitary adenoma.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 599

choices.text: Oral doxycycline for the pregnant woman
Intravenous acyclovir for suspected viral infection
Supportive care, as the rash is self-limiting in pregnancy

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks gestation presents with a low-grade fever, malaise, and a generalized rash. She reports a history of a recent tick bite while camping in a wooded area. On examination, there are multiple erythematous, circular lesions with central clearing on her arms and legs. Fetal ultrasound shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a low-grade fever, malaise, and erythematous circular lesions with central clearing following a tick bite is suggestive of Lyme disease. In pregnancy, the preferred approach is supportive care without the use of specific antibiotics. The rash is self-limiting, and the majority of pregnant women with Lyme disease have favorable outcomes without fetal complications. Oral doxycycline, which is effective against Lyme disease, is contraindicated in pregnancy due to potential adverse effects on fetal bone and teeth development. Therefore, the most appropriate management in this case is supportive care.

Reference: Jeffcoate's Principles of Gynaecology, 8th edition, page no 310

questions.text: A 40 year old female patient presented with ascites and USG is suggestive of cirrhosis of liver. HIV, HBsAg, HCV are negative. We suspect Autoimmune Hepatitis. Auto-antibodies of Autoimmune Hepatitis includes all except?
questions.solution:
Among the characteristic auto-antibodies associated with Autoimmune Hepatitis, the one that does not typically include is (D) ANCA (Anti-Neutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibodies).

The following auto-antibodies are more commonly associated with Autoimmune Hepatitis:

  • ANA (Anti-Nuclear Antibodies): These antibodies are often detected in patients with autoimmune hepatitis.
  • Anti-SLA (Anti-Soluble Liver Antigen): Anti-SLA antibodies are specific to autoimmune hepatitis and are considered a marker for the condition.
  • Anti LKM-1 (Anti-Liver/Kidney Microsomal Type 1 Antibodies): These antibodies are associated with autoimmune hepatitis, particularly in type 2 autoimmune hepatitis.

Anti-Neutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibodies (ANCA) are more commonly associated with other autoimmune conditions like ANCA-associated vasculitis (e.g., granulomatosis with polyangiitis, microscopic polyangiitis) and are not typically considered characteristic auto-antibodies for autoimmune hepatitis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2614

questions.text: Aplasia is most commonly seen in which vessel?
questions.solution:
Aplasia is the most common congenital venous anomaly. It is most commonly seen in the inferior vena cava, but can also occur in other veins, such as the femoral veins and the hepatic veins.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1047

questions.text: Which subtype of the Interstitial lung disease can present like Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Hamman-Rich Syndrome is an acute and rapidly progressive form of interstitial lung disease that can present similarly to Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). This subtype of interstitial lung disease is characterized by diffuse alveolar damage, severe lung inflammation, and acute respiratory failure. It is often associated with a rapidly worsening clinical course, which is why it can resemble ARDS in its presentation.

The other options (A) Desquamative Interstitial Pneumonia, (C) Usual Interstitial Pneumonitis, and (D) Cryptogenic Organizing Pneumonia may have different clinical presentations and characteristics compared to Hamman-Rich Syndrome and ARDS.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2195

choices.text: The TDLU is the most active part of the breast tissue
TDLU responds to a number of hormones namely: oestrogen, progesterone, prolactin and growth hormone
Approximately 10-100 lobules empty via ductules into a lactiferous duct
About 20 % of the ductolobular tissue is located in the upper outer quadrant and about 50 % in the central region

questions.text: All are true about the surgical anatomy of the breast except
questions.solution:
The TDLU is the most active part of the breast tissue and responds to a number of hormones: namely, oestrogen, progesterone, prolactin and growth hormone. There are five to nine major lactiferous (milk) ducts carrying milk from the lobes. Approximately 10-100 lobules empty via ductules into a lactiferous duct. Each lactiferous duct is lined with a spiral arrangement of contractile myoepithelial cells.

Most diseases of the breast arise from the TDLU. About 50% of the ductolobular tissue is located in the upper outer quadrant and about 20% in the central region. Hence, during breast examination particular attention must be paid to the upper outer quadrant, retroareolar region and the nipple- areola complex.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 914

questions.text: In which of the following heart diseases is maternal mortality during pregnancy found to be the highest:
questions.solution:
Eisenmenger's syndrome is the presence of secondary pulmonary hypertension that develops from any cardiac lesion.

  • The syndrome develops when increased pulmonary blood flow due to left to right shunt produces a right side pressure more than left side and hence reversal of shunt occurs and subsequently cyanosis develops.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 24th Edition, Page no 1028

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding in an infant?
questions.solution:
• Painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding in an infant may be caused by Meckel diverticulum, intestinal duplication, or lymphonodular hyperplasia.
  • Other causes of lower gastrointestinal bleeding in infants who typically present with apparent abdominal pain include infectious colitis, malrotation with volvulus, anal fissure, and intussusception.

The pancreas secretes bicarbonate, which optimizes the pH in the intestine for enzyme activation

questions.text: All of the following are true about specific functions of the gut EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
The colon is primarily responsible for stool dehydration, decreasing volumes from 1000-1500 mL to 100-200 mL.

The stomach triturates and mixes the food bolus with pepsin and acid. The stomach also secretes intrinsic factor, which is necessary for vitamin B12 absorption.

Gastric acid sterilizes the upper gut.

Pancreatic juice contains enzymes for carbohydrate, protein, and fat digestion as well as bicarbonate to optimize the pH for enzyme activation.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2381

questions.text: Persistent hyperparathyroidism is defined as an elevated calcium with in _____ of surgical intervention and Recurrent hyperparathyroidism is defined as hypercalcemia occurring _____ after surgery but with an intervening period of normocalcemia.
questions.solution:
Persistent hyperparathyroidism

Persistent hyperparathyroidism is defined as an elevated calcium within 6 weeks of surgical intervention. For all parathyroid operations (minimally invasive parathyroidectomy [MIP] and bilateral exploration) the rate of persistent hypercalcaemia is approximately 6% in sporadic disease and between 16% and 20% in hereditary disease.

Recurrent hyperparathyroidism

Recurrent hyperparathyroidism is defined as hypercalcaemia occurring 6 months after surgery but with an intervening period of normocalcaemia. Common causes include missed pathology at the first operation; hyperplasia in remaining or auto-transplanted tissue; parathyromatosis; or, very rarely, the development of a second parathyroid adenoma.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 887

choices.text: Irregular vaginal bleeding may be a side effect
Used in combination with oral contraceptive pills

questions.text: A 27 year old lactating mother is taking progesterone only pills. True statement about Minipill is:
questions.solution:
Minipill can be used during lactation (i.e., option 'c' is correct).

It is not used in combination with other pills therefore option 'b' is incorrect.

Minipill

'Ectopic pregnancy is not prevented as effectively as intrauterine pregnancy. Although the overall incidence of ectopic pregnancy is not increased, when pregnancy occurs (with minipill use) the clinician must suspect that it is more likely to be ectopic. A previous ectopic pregnancy should not be regarded as a contraindication to the minipill.'

-Leon

Main side effect of Minipill /progesterone only pill: Irregular bleeding and amenorrhea (i.e., option 'a' is correct).

Pearl index-3%

Reference: Williams Gynecology, 1st Edition, Page no. 922

questions.text: Hormones plays a major role in fetal growth. All the following hormones are major contributors in fetal growth except?
questions.solution:
• Human fetus secretes thyroxine from the 12th week of gestation. Thyroxine and insulin have an important role in regulating tissue accretion and differentiation in the fetus. Both hormones are required for normal growth and development, particularly during late gestation.
  • Glucocorticoids also play an important role, primarily towards the end of gestation and influence the prepartum maturation of organs such as liver, lungs and gastrointestinal tract.
  • Growth hormone, though present in high levels in fetus, it's not known to influence fetal growth.

Reference: Ghai essential pediatrics, 9th edition, page no 8

questions.text: Severe disability has Glasgow outcome scale of
questions.solution:
The Glasgow Outcome Scale (GOS) is a scale used to assess the overall outcome and disability of patients with brain injuries, particularly after head trauma. It categorizes patients into one of the following five categories:

  • Dead
  • Vegetative State
  • Severe Disability
  • Moderate Disability
  • Good Recovery

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 369

questions.text: Match the correct pair of the Genetic disease and gene involved.
questions.solution:
Cystic fibrosis - CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator): Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disease caused by mutations in the CFTR gene. These mutations lead to the production of thick and sticky mucus in the respiratory, digestive, and reproductive systems. It results in a range of symptoms, including respiratory issues and digestive problems.

Malignant hyperthermia - RYR1 (ryanodine receptor 1): Malignant hyperthermia is a rare genetic disorder triggered by certain types of anesthesia. It's associated with mutations in the RYR1 gene. When a susceptible individual is exposed to triggering agents, their muscle cells release excessive calcium, leading to uncontrolled muscle contractions, high fever, and potentially life-threatening complications.

Wilson disease - ATP7B: Wilson disease is a genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of copper in the body, leading to liver and neurological problems. It is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which is involved in copper transport and regulation in the body.

Marfan syndrome - FBN1 (fibrillin-1): Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene. It affects connective tissues, leading to a range of features, including tall stature, joint hypermobility, and cardiovascular issues, such as aortic aneurysms.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3667

questions.text: Which maneuver is seen in this image?
questions.solution:
The Pringle maneuver is a surgical maneuver that is used to temporarily occlude the hepatic artery and portal vein during liver surgery.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, page no 381

questions.text: The major contribution of the amniotic fluid after 20 weeks of gestation:
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid is the fluid that surrounds and protects the developing fetus during pregnancy. It serves several essential functions, including cushioning the fetus, regulating temperature, allowing fetal movement, and preventing compression of the umbilical cord. The composition of amniotic fluid changes over the course of pregnancy.

After 20 weeks of gestation, the primary source of amniotic fluid is fetal urine. The fetus swallow amniotic fluid, processes it through its kidneys, and excretes urine into the amniotic sac. This process helps maintain the volume and composition of the amniotic fluid, and it is essential for the development of the fetal urinary system. Fetal lung fluid (b) and fetal skin (c) do contribute to the amniotic fluid but are not the major sources. Ultrafiltrate and maternal plasma (d) are not primary contributors to amniotic fluid after 20 weeks of gestation.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 24th Edition, Page no 102

questions.text: According to neonatal resuscitation protocol, chest compression to breathing ratio is?
questions.solution:
• For resuscitation, Chest compression to Breathing ratio is 3:1
  • Rate of chest compression is 60/min

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, page no 981

questions.text: Which of the following structure is derived from neural crest cells?
questions.solution:
Ectoderm: Epidermis, hair follicles, sweat coils, sebaceous glands

Mesoderm: Dermis, Vessels, Nerves, Arrectors

Neural crest: Melanocyte, Merkel cells

Mesenchyme: Langerhans cells

Melanocytes are derived from the neural crest. The other structures listed are derived from the ectoderm (epidermis, hair follicles, sweat coils, sebaceous glands), mesoderm (dermis, vessels, nerves, arrectores pilorum), or mesenchyme (Langerhans cells).

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, page no 15

questions.text: A 40 year old female had a skin lesion over the face at the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks. It is called Lupus pernio. In which disease this type of lesions seen?
questions.solution:
Skin involvement is eventually identified in over a third of patients with sarcoidosis.

The classic cutaneous lesions include erythema nodosum, maculopapular lesions, hyper- and hypopigmentation, keloid formation, and subcutaneous nodules.

A specific complex of involvement of the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks is referred to as lupus pernio and is diagnostic for a chronic form of sarcoidosis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2832

questions.text: What is the most common site of extragonadal germ cell tumours
questions.solution:
Germ cell tumour: The anterior mediastinum is the most common site of extragonadal germ cell tumours. They account for 13% of all mediastinal masses and cysts and contain elements from all three cell types (mesoderm, endoderm and ectoderm). They tend to present in young adults and 75% are benign and cystic, although they may cause compression of neighboring structures; hence, dermoid cysts are best excised. Malignancy is suspected if elevated levels of serum alpha-fetoprotein, human chorionic gonadotropin and carcinoembryonic antigen are detected. After initial treatment with chemotherapy, a patient with tumour marker normalization and a persistent mass on CT may be considered for surgical resection. If tumour markers fail to normalize, further chemotherapy is usually offered.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 931

questions.text: All of the following are predisposing factors for systemic lupus erythematosus EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency is not a predisposing factor for SLE. It is a condition associated with hereditary angioedema, a different medical condition that involves recurrent episodes of severe swelling in various parts of the body.

The other factors mentioned (B, C, and D) are associated with an increased risk of developing SLE:

  • Female sex: SLE is more common in females, and the female-to-male ratio for SLE is significantly higher.
  • HLA-DR alleles: Certain human leukocyte antigen (HLA) alleles, specifically those in the HLA-DR family, are known to be associated with an increased risk of SLE.
  • Ultraviolet (UV) light: UV light exposure, such as from sunlight, is considered a potential trigger for SLE flares in individuals who are already predisposed to the condition. UV light exposure is not a direct cause of SLE but can exacerbate the disease in susceptible individuals.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2737

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are used in Cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
• Ivacaftor, a small molecule potentiator of the CFTR mutation, G551D (present in ~5% of patients). Ivacaftor activates the CFTR-G551D mutant protein, a class III CFTR mutation that results in protein localized to the plasma membrane but loss of chloride channel function.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page no 2109

TREATMENT:

  • Extension splint of DIPJ 6-8 weeks. With encouragement of PIPJ ROM
  • CRPP/ORIF (dorsal midline incision with simple pin fixation), indicated in volar

subluxation of the distal phalanx. Relative indications: the bony fragment >40% of

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition, Page no 390

questions.text: A hypomanic episode has to last at least-
questions.solution:
A hypomanic episode is a period of abnormally elevated mood and energy that lasts at least 4 days but less than 7 days. It is less severe than a manic episode and does not cause significant impairment in social or occupational functioning.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th Edition, page no 216

questions.text: For a 30 year old lady with failed medical treatment of uterine polyp, the surgical treatment of uterine polyp can be:
questions.solution:
Endometrial polyp -- Hysteroscopy and resection (best) Removal by ovum forceps. In case of recurrence and, if family completed-uterine curettage hysterectomy

Cervical polyp--Twisting of the pedicle

Big fibroid in vagina-

  • Removal of polyp by morcellation
  • If associated with inversion enucleate

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th Edition, Page no. 287, 288

questions.text: 23 year old female patient came to casualty with lacerated wound over the right forearm after 2 days of injury. Surgeon on duty decided to leave wound open after proper cleaning and debridement of non-viable tissue. After 7 days edges were opposed when the wound is clean. This type of wound healing is called
questions.solution:
TYPES OF WOUND HEALING

There are different types of healing. Primary healing is also known as healing by first intention. This occurs when there is direct approximation of the wound edges and is the aim of treatment. When there are no adverse influences, these wounds heal well and leave the best scar. Delayed primary healing occurs when the wound edges are not opposed immediately, which may be necessary in contaminated or untidy wounds. After debridement of non-viable tissue and when the wound is clean, the wound edges may be surgically approximated. This is also called healing by tertiary intention.

Secondary healing or healing by secondary intention occurs in wounds that are left open and allowed to heal by granulation, contraction and re-epithelialization.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no 28

questions.text: The image shows presence of:
questions.solution:
Acanthocytes, also known as spur cells, are a type of red blood cell with an abnormal shape. They have irregularly spaced, spiky projections on their cell membranes, which give them a characteristic appearance. These spiky projections are often irregular in length and distribution, creating a jagged or irregular edge to the red blood cell.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 434

questions.text: In a young female of reproductive age with regular menstrual cycles of 28 days, ovulation occurs around 14th day of periods. When is the first polar body extruded?
questions.solution:
1. Most of the standard text books say the first polar body is expelled just before or shortly before ovulation.
  2. Which does not mean that it is released 24 hours before ovulation.
  3. 'While still in the ovary the ovum is in the primary oocyte stage. Shortly before it is released from ovarian follicle (i.e., shortly before ovulation), its nucleus divides by meiosis and a first polar body is expelled from the nucleus of the oocyte. The primary oocyte then becomes the secondary oocyte. In this process each of the 23 unpaired of chromosomes loses one of its partners which become the first polar body that is expelled. This leaves 23 unpaired chromosomes in the secondary oocyte. It is at this time that the ovum, still in the secondary oocyte stage is ovulated into the abdominal cavity.'

So, first polar body is released at the time of ovulation i.e., Option 'b'.

  1. At this time second polar body is cast off. So second polar body is cast off at the time of fertilization.

Reference: Guyton's textbook of Medical Physiology, 10th Edition, page no 944

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is seen in the emergency department with a 2-day history of left groin pain and a limp. His parents deny any history of injury. Examination of the hip shows a 5° hip flexion position, 20° of abduction, internal rotation to 15°, and external rotation to 30°. His temperature is 100.9°F (38.3°C). Blood studies show a normal WBC count and the erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 18 mm/h. The C reactive protein is pending. A radiograph is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Transient synovitis is the most common cause of hip pain in children.

Males are affected more often than females and this a typical age for this problem.

Normal radiographs rule out SCFE and Perthes disease.

The normal WBC count, temperature, ability to walk and normal ESR make septic arthritis unlikely. Both juvenile arthritis and transient synovitis are diagnoses of exclusion and the subsequent clinical course would differentiate. Transient synovitis usually lasts less than 4 or 5 days.

With juvenile arthritis, the ESR usually is elevated.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition, Page no. 1662-1670.

questions.text: Prophylactic medications for migraine include all of the following except
questions.solution:
Prophylactic migraine medications include antidepressants, ergotamine, beta blockers, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, calcium channel blockers and some anticonvulsants, including divalproex, valproic acid, gabapentin or topiramate but not carbamazepine. Carbamazepine is instead used to treat cranial neuralgias.

Reference: Otologic Surgery by Brackmann, 45th edition, Page no. 794.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for blood grouping in an old blood stain?
questions.solution:
Presumptive tests for blood:

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenolphthalein test
  • Leucomalachite green test
  • Orthotolidine test
  • Luminol spray test

Confirmatory tests for blood are:

  • Microscopic examination
  • Teichmann Haemin crystal test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Spectroscopic examination
  • Electrophoresis
  • Chromatography.

For grouping in old blood stains:

  • Acid dilution test or Latte's crust method

Precipitin test is to identify the species of the blood stain/tissue.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no. 476.

choices.text: Free gas under left dome of diaphragm
Free gas under right dome of diaphragm

questions.text: Given below image shows?
questions.solution:
Above given image shows fundic gas bubble which is normal.

Do not confuse it with free gas under left dome of diaphragm. Usually free gas under diaphragm is noted on right side. For it to occur on left side very large amount of air should be present.

Reference: Chest X-Ray Survival Guide, 4th edition, Page no. 242.

questions.text: A male child with mild painful swelling in the scalp for 3 months associated with hair loss. The patient has a dog pet at house. What will be diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Kerion is a severe inflammatory reaction of the scalp that is caused by a dermatophyte infection. It is characterized by a boggy, erythematous plaque with hair loss and pustules.

Kerion: a severe inflammatory reaction, resulting from a delayed immune response to the fungus. This pattern progresses to form a painful, erythematous, boggy plaque, with associated alopecia and scattered pustules.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page no. 450.

choices.text: An episode of depression occurring during dysthymia.
An episode of depression occurring during cyclothymia.

questions.text: What is double depression?
questions.solution:
Double depression is a term used to describe an episode of major depression that occurs during a period of dysthymia. Dysthymia is a chronic form of depression that lasts for at least 2 years.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no. 228.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient on USG shows 3 × 4 cm clear ovarian cyst on right side. Next line of management is:
questions.solution:
Note: OCP's are not given routinely for ovarian masses as they decrease the risk of developing new cysts but do not hasten the resolution of existing cyst.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 6th Edition, Page no. 472.

choices.text: It occurs as a result of anaerobic muscle metabolism and classically described as debilitating cramp like pain felt in the muscle
Present on talking the first step
Relieved by rest in both the standing and sitting position

questions.text: All are the features of 'Intermittent claudication' except
questions.solution:
Intermittent claudication is pain in the legs that is caused by reduced blood flow to the muscles during exercise. It is typically relieved by rest.

Features of intermittent claudication include:

  • Pain in the calves, thighs, or buttocks that is brought on by exercise and relieved by rest.
  • Pain that is worse with uphill walking or stair climbing.
  • Pain that is relieved within 5 minutes of rest.
  • A cold, pale or numb foot or leg.
  • Intermittent claudication is not typically present on talking the first step.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 998.

questions.text: A 40 year old I.V. drug user presented to you with Weight loss, cough with expectoration and night sweats since 1 month. On CXR, there is Left upper lobe cavitary lesion and sputum AFB positive and he also positive for HIV. So how to start Anti tubercular treatment and Anti retroviral treatment?
questions.solution:
In a patient with a left upper lobe cavitary lesion, positive sputum acid-fast bacilli(AFB) for tuberculosis, weight loss, cough with expectoration, night sweats and HIV positivity, the management should typically involve starting Anti-Tubercular Treatment(ATT) before initiating Anti-Retroviral Treatment(ART).

The recommended approach is to start ATT first to address the active tuberculosis infection. Once the patient's tuberculosis has been adequately controlled(usually after an initial period of ATT), then Anti-Retroviral Treatment(ART) can be introduced.

So, the correct choice is (A) Start ATT first. This sequence is often followed to ensure that the tuberculosis infection is under control before introducing ART, which can be important in managing both conditions effectively while minimizing the risk of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome(IRIS).

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no. 1377.

choices.text: Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo oophorectomy

questions.text: A 38-year-old primiparous woman suffering from endometriosis is subjected to diagnostic laparoscopy. Findings indicate - uterus normal, both the ovaries show presence of chocolate cysts; endometriotic deposits are seen on the round ligament of right side, both fallopian tubes and pouch of Douglas; moderately dense adhesions are present between the fallopian tubes and in the pouch of Douglas. The treatment of choice in this case is:
questions.solution:
In the question it is given, dense adhesions and chocolate cyst are present which cannot be fully treated by medical therapy and so, some form of surgery is required.

Main question is whether we would like to go for conservative surgery or radical surgery(i.e., TAH with BSO)

Remember: mostly in endometriosis conservative surgery is done.

Conservative surgery: The clinical situations involving conservative surgery include ovarian endometrioma, pelvic adhesions, peritoneal implants and deep infiltrative rectovaginal septum disease.

In addition, laser laparoscopy can be used in order to perform uterine nerve ablation.

Reference: William's Gynecology, 1st Edition, Page no. 235.

questions.text: A newborn at birth has HR 80/min, no spontaneous breathing and no grimace on stimulation. His limbs appear bluish in color. The APGAR score for the baby will be?
questions.solution:
APGAR is routinely measured at 1 min and 5 min.

0-3 = Severely depressed

4-6 = Moderately depressed

7-10 = Normal

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, Page no. 798.

questions.text: 12-year-old girl has painless bowing of the tibia. Radiographs and a biopsy specimen are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has osteo fibrous dysplasia. The radiographic differential diagnosis includes osteo fibrous dysplasia, fibrous dysplasia and adamantinoma. Histology shows a fibro-osseous lesion with prominent osteoblastic rimming but a lack of epithelial nests.

Adamantinoma is a low-grade malignancy that typically is located in the anterior tibial cortex and has a soap bubble appearance. Histologically, it is similar to osteo fibrous dysplasia but includes epithelial nests of cells.

Treatment requires resection. Fibrous dysplasia usually does not require biopsy; however, in this patient the radiographs do not distinguish it from adamantinoma.

The radiographic findings are not typical of Ewing sarcoma or osteosarcoma. Repeat biopsy should be considered if clinical or radiographic features change.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition, Page no. 1218.

questions.text: While infiltrating local anaesthetics, to prolong the duration of action, adrenaline is added. This should be however avoided in
questions.solution:
Addition of epinephrine or less commonly phenylephrine causes vasoconstriction at the site of administration. The consequent decreased absorption reduces the peak local anesthetic concentration in blood, facilitates neuronal uptake, enhances the quality of analgesia, prolongs the duration of analgesia and limits toxic side effects. However, they cannot be used in parts having end arterial supply, as it will cause distal necrosis.

Reference: Morgan anaesthesia, 6th edition, Page no. 267.

questions.text: A patient presents with acute abdomen. He is scheduled for laparotomy. The patient is a known case of chronic kidney and liver disease. What neuromuscular blocking agent can be used
questions.solution:
The most suitable option in this scenario is c. Atracurium as:

Metabolism: Atracurium is metabolized by ester hydrolysis, which is independent of the liver and kidneys. This means it does not rely on liver or kidney function for its breakdown and elimination, making it a safer option in patients with kidney and liver disease.

Organ Dysfunction: Atracurium's breakdown products are non-toxic and do not accumulate in the body, even in the presence of liver or kidney dysfunction. This is important in patients with compromised organ function.

Short Duration: Atracurium has an intermediate duration of action and its effects can be reversed with medications like neostigmine when necessary.

Hemodynamic Stability: Atracurium has minimal impact on hemodynamics, which can be an advantage in patients with liver and kidney disease, who may be more sensitive to cardiovascular changes.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, Edition 5, Page no. 408.

questions.text: The pain associated with acute urinary tract obstruction is a result of which of the following?
questions.solution:
In acute urinary tract obstruction, pain is due to distention of the collecting system or renal capsule.

Acutely, there is a compensatory increase in renal blood flow when kidney function is impaired by obstruction, which further exacerbates capsular stretch.

Eventually, vasodilatory prostaglandins act to preserve renal function when glomerular filtration rate has decreased.

Medullary blood flow decreases as the pressure of the obstruction further inhibits the renal parenchyma from perfusing; however, the ensuing chronic renal destruction may occur without substantial pain.

When an obstruction has been relieved, there is a post obstructive diuresis that is mediated by relief of tubular pressure, increased solute load(per nephron) and natriuretic factors. There can be an extreme amount of diuresis, but this is not painful.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no. 2374.

questions.text: Which of the following is the Voiding symptom of lower urinary tract symptoms?
questions.solution:
Voiding symptoms are those that occur during urination. They include:

Hesitancy: Delay or difficulty in starting to urinate.

Poor flow: Weak or interrupted stream of urine.

Intermittent stream: Urine flow stops and starts.

Dribbling: Urine leakage after urination.

Sensation of poor bladder emptying: Feeling that the bladder is not completely empty after urination.

Episodes of near retention: Difficulty passing urine.

Hesitancy is a voiding symptom, while the other options are storage symptoms.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no. 1523.

questions.text: The investigation of choice in 55-year-old post-menopausal women who has presented with postmenopausal bleeding is:
questions.solution:
Postmenopausal bleeding most commonly occurs due to atrophic changes but can also occur due to Ca endometrium or Ca cervix.

Hence, in case of postmenopausal bleeding, ruling out both endometrial and cervical cancer is always a priority. Hence, fractional curettage is the right answer.

TVS can detect uterine pathology, but histopathological diagnosis is a must in such cases.

Pap is positive only in 30-50% of Ca endometrium and so not useful. TVS and CA-125 are screening methods for ovarian CA and hence not applicable here.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 6th Edition, Page no. 560.

questions.text: Following is Anterior Segment photograph of a patient who has history of Cataract surgery done 6 months ago. He has come to the OPD with complain of decrease in vision in operated eye. Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
In the photograph it can be seen that IOL is decentered superiorly. This is called sunrise Syndrome

Complications related to IOL:

Malposition of IOL: The IOL may be decentered subluxated or dislocated leading to

Sunset syndrome: Subluxated inferiorly Sunrise syndrome: Subluxated superiorly

Windshield wiper syndrome: Lens keeps moving with movement of head

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Page no. 401.

questions.text: NACO kit 1 contains:
questions.solution:
The NACO kit 1 contains azithromycin and cefixime. It is used for the treatment of sexually transmitted infections(STIs) such as gonorrhea and chlamydia.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page no. 987.

choices.text: Advise MTP as it is a nonviable pregnancy
High probability of nonviable pregnancy-but still repeat scan after 7 days to confirm
Can be ectopic pregnancy - give methotrexate
High probability of viable pregnancy-repeat scan after 7 days

questions.text: A P2 + 1 female comes with amenorrhea of 5 weeks. Her UPT is positive. On performing USG, the gestational sac and yolk sac are seen in uterus but there is no fetal cardiac activity and fetal pole is not visible. CRL is 8 mm and MSD is 28 mm. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
• Gestational sac is visible by TVS at » 4.5 weeks when β-hCG is 1500 to 2000 mIu/ml
  • Yolk sac is visible by TVS at » 5.5 weeks when MSD(mean sac diameter) is 10 mm
  • Embryo is visible by TVS at 5-6 weeks when MSD = 15-20 mm
  • Fetal cardiac activity can be detected at 6-6.5 weeks with an embryonic length(CRL=) 1-5 mm and MSD of 13-18 mm.

An embryonic gestation is diagnosed when the mean gestational sac diameter measures³ 20 mm and no embryo is seen. Embryonic death is also diagnosed if an embryo measuring³ 10 mm has no cardiac activity. So, in the question - MSD is 28 mm and CRL 8 mm and still no cardiac activity or fetal pole is visible. It has to be a nonviable pregnancy.

In this case whether we should perform immediate MTP or repeat scan after 7 days is suggested by high risk Pregnancy 4/e, P 108.

  • If fetal pole is not seen and MSD³ 25 mm then there is high probability of a non-viable pregnancy. Repeat scan with another examiner or after 7 days to confirm.
  • If fetal pole is seen then measure CRL. If CRL³ 7 mm there is high probability of nonviable pregnancy. Repeat scan should be done after 7 days to confirm.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 24th Edition, Page no. 355.

choices.text: The initial treatment is with slow rewarming in a bath at 30°C
The cold injury produces early microvascular damage similar to that of ischaemia - reperfusion injury
Surgery usually does not play a role in its management which is conservative, until there is absolute demarcation of the level of injury

questions.text: All are false about the cold injuries except
questions.solution:
Frostbite injuries affect the peripheries in cold climates. The initial treatment is with rapid rewarming in a bath at 42°C. The cold injury produces delayed microvascular damage similar to that of ischaemia-reperfusion injury. The level of damage is difficult to assess and surgery usually does not play a role in its management, which is conservative, until there is absolute demarcation of the level of injury.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no. 680.

questions.text: A 54 year old lady complains of contact bleeding. She has positive pap smear. The next line of management is:
questions.solution:
A 54 year old patient presenting with post coital bleeding and positive pap smear raises suspicion of carcinoma cervix/CIN which needs to be confirmed(as pap smear is only a screening procedure).

In the question it is not mentioned whether lesion is visible nor the size of lesion is given so we take it to be invisible.

As already discussed for invisible lesion, colposcopy should be done to confirm the diagnosis.

Reference: Williams Gynecology, 1st Edition, Page no. 628.

questions.text: Match the following antihypertensive drug class and the drug name correctly
questions.solution:
1. Renin inhibitor - 3. Aliskiren: Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor used to treat hypertension by blocking the enzyme renin.
  2. Direct Vasodilator - 1. Hydralazine: Hydralazine is a direct vasodilator that relaxes and widens blood vessels, reducing blood pressure.
  3. K+ sparing diuretic - 4. Amiloride: Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic, often used to reduce potassium loss in the urine.
  4. Central Sympatholytic - 2. Clonidine: Clonidine is a centrally acting alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that reduces sympathetic nervous system activity, leading to a decrease in blood pressure.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no. 2083.

questions.text: What is the most common familial syndrome associated with RCC?
questions.solution:
Von Hippel-Lindau(VHL) syndrome is the most common familial syndrome associated with renal cell carcinoma(RCC). It is a rare autosomal dominant disorder that is characterized by multiple pathologies, including clear-cell RCC, phaeochromocytoma, retinal angiomas and haemangioblastomas of the brainstem, cerebellum or spinal cord.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no. 1482.

choices.text: β hCG levels will be higher than normal
β hCG levels will be lower than normal
Uterus will be of normal size

questions.text:
A 36-year-old G₁P₀ woman presents for her first prenatal visit late in her first trimester of pregnancy; she complains of persistent vaginal bleeding, nausea and pelvic pain. Physical examination is notable for a gravid uterus larger than expected for gestational age. Fetal heart tones are absent.

Which of the following is most likely to be true?
questions.solution:
In the given question patient is presenting late in her first trimester of pregnancy with complains of persistent vaginal bleeding, nausea and pelvic pain. Physical examination is notable for a gravid uterus larger than expected for gestational age. Fetal heart tones are absent.

  • Twin pregnancy can be ruled out because it does not explain persistent vaginal bleeding and moreover in twin/multiple pregnancy fetal heart tones are not absent. 2 or more FHS are heard depending on the number of fetuses.
  • Concealed variety of APH does not occur in late first trimester. APH by definition means any bleeding which occurs after 28 weeks of pregnancy and up till the birth of the child and hence it can be ruled out although absent fetal tones and Fundal height more than the gestational age are seen.
  • Polyhydramnios again can be ruled out since bleeding cannot be explained by it, so we are left with molar pregnancy

The USG shown in the plate is typical snow storm appearance. Hence diagnosis is confirmed.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 24th Edition, Page no. 888.

choices.text: Associated with nasal polyposis in childhood.

questions.text: Cystic fibrosis is
questions.solution:
In cystic fibrosis, the condition has an autosomal recessive inheritance and the defect primarily affects the secretions, so ciliary beat frequency and ultrastructure are normal. Bronchiectasis and dextrocardia are features of PCD and not cystic fibrosis. However, any child presenting with nasal polyposis should be suspected of having cystic fibrosis and submitted to the appropriate sweat tests and deoxyribonucleic acid(DNA) evaluation. Up to 30% of children and 50% of adults with cystic fibrosis suffer from nasal polyposis and the majority have some degree of chronic rhinosinusitis.

Reference: Otologic Surgery by Brackmann, 45th edition, Page no. 761.

questions.text: A 9-month-old pregnant lady presents with jaundice and distension, pedal edema after delivering normal baby. Her clinical condition deteriorates with increasing abdominal distension and severe ascites. Her bilirubin is 5 mg/dL, S. alkaline phosphatase was 450 u/L and ALT(345 lu). There is tender hepatomegaly 6 cm below costal margin and ascetic fluid show protein less than 2mg%. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most common causes of acute severe liver injury in a young pregnant women are:

  • Viral hepatitis(HAV, HBV)
  • Eclampsia, preeclampsia(HELLP syndrome)
  • Acute fatty liver of pregnancy
  • Budd-Chiari syndrome

Let us discuss each option separately

Preeclampsia and eclampsia/HELLP syndrome:

  • It is the most common cause of abnormal liver function test in women.
  • Aminotransferases are modestly elevated.
  • But in these case delivery of the fetus is followed by rapid normalization of the hepatic abnormalities.
  • Moreover, the question does not mention any history of PIH, hemolysis and thrombocytopenia(HELLP syndrome).

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy:

  • Acute fatty liver develops in the third trimester.
  • Jaundice develops a few days after the onset. The serum bilirubin is rarely above 10 mg/dL.
  • Alkaline phosphate is markedly elevated.
  • Aminotransferases are moderately elevated.

Fulminant hepatic failure:

  • The patient presents with features of severe acute hepatitis leading to the development of hepatic encephalopathy within 8 weeks of onset.
  • The bilirubin increases to 20-30 mg/dL.

Budd-Chiari syndrome:

  • It is a disorder characterized by thrombotic occlusion of the hepatitis veins.
  • It is a rare complication of pregnancy.
  • Most of the cases presents within few weeks of delivery but in several cases onset occurs during pregnancy.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no. 1862.

questions.text:
Match the following:

1. Adult transverse fracture
2. Uninjured bone
3. Torus or buckle fracture
4. Greenstick fracture
questions.solution:
Adult transverse fracture: A break in a bone that is perpendicular to the long axis of the bone.

Uninjured bone: A bone that has not been fractured.

Torus or buckle fracture: A fracture that occurs in the cortex of a bone without displacement.

Greenstick fracture: A fracture that occurs in the cortex of a bone with incomplete displacement.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no. 422.

questions.text: In Body Dysmorphic Disorder the most common body part involved is-
questions.solution:
Most common imagined defect in Body Dysmorphic disorder is seen in Nose > Skin

The most common body part involved in body dysmorphic disorder(BDD) is the nose. Other common body parts include the skin, hair and body shape.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no. 303.

questions.text: Hysteroscopic view shown in figure
questions.solution:
The image is a hysteroscopic view of uterine cavity. As seen, the uterine cavity is divided into 2 by a septa, hence it is a hysteroscopic view of septate uterus.

Arcuate uterus is a flat-topped uterus as seen in the HSG. Here the fundal bulge fails to develop after fusion of the ducts. The fundal myometrium is extremely thin in this case.

Reference: Jeffcoate's Principles Of Gynaecology, 8th edition, Page no. 198.

questions.text: Which type of tracheoesophageal fistula is seen below
questions.solution:
Type C tracheoesophageal fistula is a fistula between the trachea and the esophagus that occurs below the carina.

Tracheoesophageal fistula(TEF) refers to an abnormal connection between the trachea(windpipe) and the esophagus(the tube that connects the mouth to the stomach). TEF is often associated with a gap or atresia in the esophagus. The types of tracheoesophageal fistula are typically classified into several categories and the most commonly used classification is the Gross classification, which includes types A, B, C and D.

  1. Type A: Esophageal atresia without tracheoesophageal fistula. This means that the upper part of the esophagus does not connect to the lower part and there is no abnormal connection to the trachea.
  2. Type B: Proximal esophageal atresia with a blind upper esophageal pouch and a tracheoesophageal fistula connecting the distal esophagus to the trachea. In this type, the upper part of the esophagus ends in a blind pouch and the lower part is connected to the trachea.
  3. Type C: Distal esophageal atresia with a blind lower esophageal pouch and a tracheoesophageal fistula connecting the proximal esophagus to the trachea. This means that the lower part of the esophagus ends in a blind pouch and the upper part is connected to the trachea. This is the type mentioned in the question.
  4. Type D: Double tracheoesophageal fistula. In this type, there are two fistulas-one connecting the upper esophagus to the trachea and another connecting the lower esophagus to the trachea.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no. 264.

questions.text: An 18 year old boy is asymptomatic. On ECG, he has a short PR interval with delta waves. Which of the following is not required for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical diagnosis of the patient is Wolf-Parkinson white syndrome.

These patients have a bypass tract that allows conduction of impulses from atria to ventricles without having to be subjected to the decremental property of AV node.

Invasive electrophysiologic study is recommended to if pathway leads to rapid ventricular rates and in same setting curative catheter ablation can be done.

B blocker and vagal maneuvers can be done at onset of episode.

Walking on treadmill will lead to sympathetic stimulation and precipitate arrhythmia and thus would not be recommended for patient of WPW.

Rapid pre-exited tachycardia should be treated with electrical cardioversion or intravenous procainamide or ibutilide.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no. 1897.

questions.text: All are the example of exudative type of ascitis except
questions.solution:
Exudative ascites is caused by increased capillary permeability or decreased hydrostatic pressure in the portal venous system. It is typically high in protein and has a low albumin-globulin ratio.

Examples of exudative ascites include:

  • Cardiac ascites
  • Cirrhosis
  • Malignant ascites
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Pancreatic ascites

Portal vein thrombosis is a cause of non-exudative ascites.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no. 1092.

questions.text: Below shown instrument is used for all except:
questions.solution:
SIM'S SPECULUM

Material: Stainless steel.

Sterilization: Autoclaving and boiling.

Uses

  1. Gynecologic
    1. Routine gynecological examination 10 visualize vagina and cervix
    2. To collect discharge from posterior fornix
    3. Hysterosalpingography(HSG)
    4. Gynecological operations.
  2. Obstetric
    1. Routine per speculum examination
    2. Manual vacuum aspiration(MVA), first trimester medical termination of pregnancy(MTP)
    3. Cervical cerclage

Reference: JB Sharma textbook of gynecology, 1st edition, Page no. 777.

questions.text: What is the most likely clinical condition shown in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
Catatonia is a psychomotor syndrome that has been reported to occur in more than 10% of patients with acute psychiatric illnesses. Two subtypes of the syndrome have been identified. Catatonia of the retarded type is characterized by immobility, mutism, staring, rigidity and a host of other clinical signs. Excited catatonia is a less common presentation in which patients develop prolonged periods of psychomotor agitation.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page no. 634.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is admitted to the emergency room after a first episode of witnessed generalized tonic clonic seizure. She is administered lorazepam 2 mg with cessation of seizure activity. All of the following are likely possible causes of her seizure EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Age of presentation is an important consideration when an individual presents with a new onset of seizure as certain causes of seizures are more likely to present within certain age ranges, ranging from the neonatal period throughout older adulthood(age >35 years).

In individuals >35 years, the most likely causes of new-onset seizures include alcohol withdrawal, cerebrovascular disease, brain tumor, autoantibodies,

Alzheimer's disease or other neurodegenerative disease and a range of metabolic disorders. These disorders can include either hyper or hypoglycemia, uremia, hepatic failure and a host of electrolyte abnormalities or acid-base disorders.

Inherited disorders of ion channels have been implicated in a variety of rare epilepsy syndromes.

These genetic disorders typically present in childhood and rarely after the age of 18.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no. 3310.

questions.text: Above test is used to diagnose which nerve injury?
questions.solution:
Muscles of the thenar eminence: Out of the three muscles of the thenar eminence, only two can be examined for their isolated action.

These are as follows:

  1. Abductor pollicis brevis: The action of this muscle is to draw the thumb forwards at right angle to the palm. The patient is asked to lay his hand flat on the table with palm facing the ceiling. A pen is held above the thumb and the patient is asked to touch the pen with tip of his thumb. This is called the 'pen test'.
  2. Opponens pollicis: The function of this muscle is to oppose the tip of the thumb to other fingers. Apposition is a swinging movement of the thumb across the palm and not a simple adduction. The latter movement is by the adductor pollicis muscle supplied by the ulnar nerve.

questions.text: A 4-year-old female child has crampy abdominal pain and a rash mainly on the back of her leg and buttocks as well as on the extensor surface of his forearm. Laboratory analysis reveals proteinuria and microscopic hematuria. She most likely is a case of
questions.solution:
American college of rheumatology classification criteria

Two of the following criteria must be present:

  • Palpable purpura
  • Age at onset ≤20 year
  • Bowel angina(postprandial abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea)
  • Biopsy demonstrating intramural granulocytes in small arterioles and/or venules.

European league against rheumatism/pediatric rheumatology european society criteria

Palpable purpura(in absence of coagulopathy or thrombocytopenia) and 1 or more of the following criteria must be present:

  • Abdominal pain(acute, diffuse, colicky pain)
  • Arthritis or arthralgia
  • Biopsy of affected tissue demonstrating predominant immunoglobulin A deposition
  • Renal involvement(proteinuria >3 grams/24 hour), hematuria or red cell casts

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, Page no. 1218.

questions.text: Identify the following flap:

A bipedicle flap is a flap with two pedicles, which are blood vessels that supply blood to the flap. This type of flap is often used to reconstruct defects in the face and hands.

questions.text: All of the following agents have been shown to have disease-modifying antirheumatic drug efficacy in patients with rheumatoid arthritis EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, Naproxen(D) is not a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug(DMARD) used to treat rheumatoid arthritis.

The other options:

  1. Infliximab - Infliximab is a DMARD and a tumor necrosis factor(TNF) inhibitor commonly used to treat rheumatoid arthritis.
  2. Leflunomide - Leflunomide is a DMARD often used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.
  3. Methotrexate - Methotrexate is one of the most commonly used DMARDs in the management of rheumatoid arthritis.

These medications(A, B and C) are all DMARDs, which have been shown to be effective in modifying the course of rheumatoid arthritis by slowing down disease progression and reducing joint damage. Naproxen(D), on the other hand, is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug(NSAID) commonly used for pain relief and reducing inflammation but is not classified as a DMARD and does not have disease-modifying properties.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no. 2761.

questions.text: Identify the fibroid based on FIGO classification:
questions.solution:
The fibroid shown in the figure is classified based on the FIGO(International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) classification system. The FIGO classification categorizes uterine fibroids(leiomyomas) into different types based on their location and extent within the uterine wall.

The correct answer is C. Type 5. In the FIGO classification, type 5 fibroids are described as "subserosal with ≥50% intramural component". This means that these fibroids have a significant portion within the uterine wall but are mainly protruding on the outside of the uterus(subserosal).

questions.text: A 40 year old man has been diagnosed with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. How the cysts should be present in USG to call ADPKD?
questions.solution:
A diagnosis is typically made from a positive family history consistent with autosomal dominant inheritance and multiple kidney cysts bilaterally. Renal ultrasonography is often used for presymptomatic screening of at-risk subjects and for evaluation of potential living-related kidney donors from ADPKD families.

The presence of at least two renal cysts(unilateral or bilateral) is sufficient for diagnosis among at-risk subjects between 15 and 29 years of age with a sensitivity value of 96% and specificity value of 100%.

The presence of at least two cysts in each kidney and at least four cysts in each kidney, respectively, is required for the diagnosis among at-risk subjects aged 30-59 years and aged ≥60 years with a sensitivity value of 100% and specificity value of 100%.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no. 2351.

questions.text: A 50 year old patient with signs of peripheral neuropathy is found to have diabetes mellitus. He has no ocular symptoms. When would you refer this patient for retina evaluation?
questions.solution:
Since the age of the patient is 50 years, it is highly likely that the patient has type II diabetes mellitus, which is insidious in onset.

Hence though patient has no ocular complaints, the fundus examination for retina evaluation should be done immediately.

The significance of this problem is highlighted by the finding that individuals with DM are 25 times more likely to become legally blind than individuals without DM.

Blindness is primarily the result of progressive diabetic retinopathy and clinically significant macular edema.

Diabetic retinopathy is classified into two stages: non-proliferative and proliferative. Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy usually appears late in the first decade or early in the second decade of hyperglycemia and is marked by retinal vascular microaneurysms, blot hemorrhages and cotton-wool spots.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no. 3122.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with a closed supracondylar fracture of the distal humerus is unable to flex the distal interphalangeal(DIP) joint of his index finger and the interphalangeal(IP) joint of his thumb. questions.text: A 64-year-old male is evaluated in the hospital for congestive heart failure, renal failure, and polyneuropathy. Blood investigation shows Urea 90 mg/dL and a creatinine of 6.3 mg/dL. Hematocrit was 24%, WBC and platelet counts were normal. Urinalysis was remarkable for 3+ proteinuria but no cellular casts. Further evaluation included an echocardiography showing Left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following tests is most likely to diagnose the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
In this case, the most likely diagnosis is Amyloidosis. To definitively diagnose amyloidosis, a tissue biopsy is required. Among the options provided, a (A) Bone marrow biopsy is the most appropriate test for diagnosing this condition as amyloid deposits can often be found in bone marrow samples. Other tests like electromyogram, fat-pad biopsy, and right heart catheterization are less likely to confirm the diagnosis of amyloidosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of a gradually enlarging, asymptomatic, brown macule on her left cheek. The lesion is 1 cm in diameter and has a slightly irregular border. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer. It typically presents as a slow-growing, pearly or translucent nodule with a rolled border. However, it can also present as a flat, brown macule, as in this case.

The other options are less likely. Actinic keratosis is a precancerous lesion that typically presents as a rough, scaly patch on sun-exposed skin. Melanoma is a more aggressive type of skin cancer that typically presents as a dark, pigmented lesion with an irregular border. Seborrheic keratoses are benign skin growths that typically appear as brown or black warty lesions on the face and trunk.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, page no 485

Boys present with progressive phimosis and white, hard preputial skin, dysuria and ballooning on micturition. Usually, circumcision is required, although some boys respond to topical corticosteroids. questions.text: All of the following are functions of wadding in a smooth bore gun except -

The top wad/overshoot wad is meant to keep the shots in place.

The wads do not cause fatal injuries.

questions.text: A 64 year old male patient was diagnosed with the Community acquired pneumonia. Which of the following is not a criteria for Severe Community acquired pneumonia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, hyperthermia (D) is not a criteria for severe community-acquired pneumonia. The presence of mental confusion (A), thrombocytopenia (B), and a reduced PaO2/FiO2 ratio (C) are criteria that can indicate the severity of community-acquired pneumonia, but hyperthermia (elevated body temperature) is not typically used as a specific criterion for determining the severity of this condition. Instead, other factors such as the extent of hypoxemia, the need for mechanical ventilation, and blood pressure are often considered in the assessment of pneumonia severity.

questions.text: What will be the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows grade 4 acne with nodules and cysts.

Isotretinoin is the most efficacious treatment for severe acne (grade 4). Isotretinoin is the only therapy that impacts on all of the major aetiological factors implicated in acne. It results in a significant reduction in sebum production, influences comedogenesis, lowers surface and ductal P. acnes and has anti-inflammatory properties. A dose of 0.5-1.0 mg/kg/day dramatically reduces acne.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with 1 month of diarrhea. He states that he has 8 to 10 loose bowel movements a day. Vital signs and physical examination are normal. Serum laboratory studies are normal. A 24-hour stool collection reveals 500 g of stool with a measured stool osmolality of 200 mOsm/L and a calculated stool osmolality of 210 mOsm/L. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's diarrhea?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of chronic diarrhea with 8 to 10 loose bowel movements a day are indicative of a secretory diarrhea, where the bowel movements are watery and osmotically active.

The normal vital signs and physical examination suggest that there is no acute or severe illness causing the diarrhea.

The serum laboratory studies are normal, which rules out common causes like malabsorption (celiac sprue), pancreatic insufficiency (chronic pancreatitis), or lactase deficiency.

The 24-hour stool collection with a measured stool osmolality of 200 mOsm/L and a calculated stool osmolality of 210 mOsm/L is consistent with a secretory diarrhea, where the measured and calculated osmolality are nearly the same.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2467

questions.text: The Inhalational agents are influenced by a number of patient and environmental factors. The factors that decrease the Minimum Alveolar Concentration or increasing the potency of the agent are
questions.solution:
MAC is reduced by:

  • Other depressant drugs (e.g., opioids, sedatives, other inhalational agents).
  • CNS depletion of catecholamines, e.g., by α-methyldopa, reserpine.
  • Hypothermia.
  • Hypoxaemia/ hypotension.
  • Pregnancy, possibly due to increased progesterone levels.
  • Extremes of age.

MAC is increased in:

  • Children.
  • Hyperthermia.
  • Hyperthyroidism.
  • Chronic alcoholism.
  • It is unaffected by duration of anaesthesia, sex, acidaemia/ alkalaemia, hypercapnia or hypocapnia.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 381

questions.text: All of the following are features of Friedreich's Ataxia except?
questions.solution:
In Friedreich's Ataxia, it is more common to find extensor plantar responses with absent or reduced lower limb reflexes, rather than brisk reflexes. Extensor plantar responses and reduced reflexes are indicative of damage to the corticospinal tracts and posterior columns of the spinal cord, which is characteristic of this condition. The presence of brisk reflexes would typically suggest a different neurological condition, such as an upper motor neuron lesion.

questions.text: Nasal carcinoma most commonly arises from?
