questions.text: 48 year old male patient undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy in view of bilateral pheochromocytoma. A day after the surgery, the patient develops hypotension with current reading of BP=90/60 mmHg ,pulse rate of 74/min .There is no evidence of loss of volume, The likely cause is
questions.solution:
Since the patient is having low BP post adrenalectomy, it implies deficiency of cortisol which plays a role in maintenance of BP.

Glucocorticoid deficiency decreases vascular response to Angiotension II, Norepinephrine and renin besides increasing prostacyclin production that leads to vasodilation.

Option A.is ruled out as it occurs due to reduced coronary blood supply.

Option C is ruled out as question mentions no evidence of volume depletion. If this was not given, the probability of postoperative bleeding would be first differential.

Option D is ruled out, septic shock takes some time to develop and there is no information about procalcitonin and blood culture report.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2976

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of limiting sulcus?
questions.solution:
• Limiting sulcus: Separates at its floor two areas which are different functionally and structurally. For example, the central sulcus between the motor and sensory areas.
  • Axial sulcus: Develops in the long axis of a rapidly growing homogeneous area. For example, the post calcarine sulcus in the long axis of the striate area.
  • Operculated sulcus: Separated by its lips in two areas, and contains a third area in the walls of the sulcus, e.g., the lunate sulcus.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 4, 8th Edition, Page No - 68

questions.text: A patient has a urine flow rate of 1 ml/min and a urine osmolality of 1200 mOsm/kg. If the descending limb of the loop of Henle is impermeable to ions, what is the concentration of the interstitial fluid in the renal medulla?
questions.solution:
The concentration of the interstitial fluid in the renal medulla can be calculated using the following formula: Urine osmolality = Interstitial fluid osmolality = Concentration of solutes in the interstitial fluid. Since the descending limb of the loop of Henle is impermeable to ions, the concentration of solutes in the interstitial fluid increases as water is reabsorbed from the descending limb into the interstitial fluid by osmosis. This creates a concentration gradient that drives the reabsorption of ions from the ascending limb of the loop of Henle. The concentration of solutes in the interstitial fluid reaches a maximum at the tip of the renal medulla, where it can be as high as 1200 mOsm/kg.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th edition, page 1012

questions.text: Which of the following sugar alcohol is responsible for cataract formation in diabetes mellitus?

questions.text: Which of the following agent shows U shaped dose response curve?
questions.solution:
A U-shaped dose-response curve implies that the response to a substance varies in a non-linear manner, where both low and high doses can have adverse effects while an intermediate range of doses may be optimal. In the case of vitamins, taking too little can lead to deficiency-related health problems, while taking too much can result in toxicity and adverse effects. Therefore, the response to vitamins often follows a U-shaped curve, where an optimal range of intake is recommended for maintaining health.

The other options listed (B) Estrogen, (C) Anti-cancer drugs, and (D) Chelators do not typically exhibit U-shaped dose-response curves in the same way that vitamins do. Estrogen, anti-cancer drugs, and chelators generally follow more typical dose-response relationships, where increasing the dose can lead to an increase in the desired effect or response.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's: The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page 55

questions.text: Most common type of Cataract seen in Retinitis Pigmentosa is
questions.solution:
Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) is a genetic disorder that affects the retina, leading to progressive vision loss. People with RP are at an increased risk of developing cataracts, which are opacities in the eye's lens that can further impair vision.

Among the different types of cataracts, posterior subcapsular cataracts are the most commonly observed in individuals with Retinitis Pigmentosa. These cataracts typically develop on the back surface of the lens just underneath the lens capsule. They can cause glare, halos, and difficulty with reading and other visual tasks. The presence of these cataracts can exacerbate the vision problems associated with RP.

So, option (B) is the correct answer, as posterior subcapsular cataracts are the most common type seen in individuals with Retinitis Pigmentosa.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 619

questions.text: Definitive host is one -
questions.solution:
There are two types of hosts-

  1. Definitive host
  2. Intermediate host

The definition of these different types of host differ according to the type of parasite that infects them.

1) For protozoan parasites

In some protozoan parasites two hosts are required to complete the life cycle. These parasites multiply sexually in one host and asexually in the other, e.g., malarial parasite. In this case

  1. Definitive host →In which sexual multiplication takes place.
  2. Intermediate host →In which asexual multiplication takes place.

Some protozoan parasites like trypanosomes require two hosts (mammalian and arthropod) to complete their life cycle; but do not multiply sexually. In such situation mammalian host is the definitive host and arthropod is Intermediate host

2) For Helminthic parasites

  1. Definitive host→ That harbors the adult form of the parasite.
  2. Intermediate host→ That harbors the larval form of the parasite.

Third different type of host is-

Paratenic host (carrier or transport host)

Where the parasite remains viable without further development.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 112

questions.text: Which gene is mutated in Cowden syndrome?
questions.solution:
Cowden syndrome, also known as Cowden disease, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple noncancerous, tumor-like growths called hamartomas and an increased risk of certain cancers, particularly breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancer. It is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder, which means that individuals with a single mutated copy of the responsible gene can develop the syndrome.

The gene that is mutated in Cowden syndrome is PTEN (phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10). PTEN is a tumor suppressor gene, and its protein product plays a critical role in regulating cell growth and division. Mutations in PTEN can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and an increased risk of developing both benign growths like hamartomas and malignant tumors like breast and thyroid cancer.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, page no 809

questions.text: A patient with history of drug abuse presented to emergency in comatose state. Vitals recorded were; respiratory rate 8/min, BP:90/60 mmHg, pulse 52 bpm. On examination there was pin point pupil. What is the probable poisoning agent in this patient?
questions.solution:
Morphine poisoning:

It may be accidental, suicidal or seen in drug abusers. In the nontolerant adult, 50 mg of morphine i.m. produces serious toxicity.

Stupor or coma, flaccidity, shallow and occasional breathing, cyanosis, pinpoint pupil, fall in BP and shock; convulsions may be seen in few, pulmonary edema occurs at terminal stages, death is due to respiratory failure.

Treatment: consists of respiratory support (positive pressure respiration also opposes pulmonary edema formation) and maintenance of BP (i.v. fluids, vasoconstrictors). Gastric lavage should be done with pot. permanganate to remove unabsorbed drug. Lavage is indicated even when morphine has been injected.

Specific antidote: Naloxone 0.4-0.8 mg i.v. repeated every 2-3 min till respiration picks up

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology 8th Edition, Page no 501

Option A & C: Mycosis fungoides and anaplastic large cell lymphoma are neoplasms of mature T cells.

Option B: Large granular lymphocytic leukemia is a neoplasm of mature T cells and NK cells

questions.text: Regarding carriers, which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Pseudo-carriers are those who carry avirulent organisms and are thus considered to be epidemiologically insignificant.

Urinary typhoid carriers are more dangerous than intestinal carriers (option A).

Carriers are not known to occur in measles (option B).

Subclinical cases may not transmit the disease always and are thus not always carriers (option C).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page no 104, 160

choices.text: Adjustment of pH to act as a buffer
Control of enzymatic functions in glucose metabolism
Conversion of water- soluble to water- insoluble proteins
Protection against oxidative and free radical damage

questions.text: What common role do superoxide dismutase, catalase and glutathione peroxidase play in lens physiology?
questions.solution:
Superoxide dismutase, catalase, and glutathione perioxidase work together to destroy the superoxide anion (O−2), protecting the lens against oxidative and free radical damage. There are no known repair mechanisms for free radical damage to proteins or membrane lipids in the lens cortex. Glutathione acts as a major free radical scavenger along with vitamin E and ascorbic acid in the lens. These 3 enzymes have no effect on the pH of the lens and do not participate in the carbohydrate metabolism of the lens. Conversion from water- soluble to water- insoluble proteins appears to be a natural (age- related) process in lens fiber maturation and does not involve an enzymatic function.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 308

questions.text: The best study to distinguish postoperative scar from tumor recurrence is
questions.solution:
PET-CT is a hybrid imaging technique that combines the metabolic information of positron emission tomography (PET) with the anatomical detail of computed tomography (CT). This makes it an ideal imaging modality for distinguishing between postoperative scar and tumor recurrence, as it can provide both functional and anatomical information.

Reference: Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery, 7th edition, Page no 529

questions.text: Binary (secondary) exposure to an antigen, results in sudden increase in -
questions.solution:
IgM is the first antibody produced in response to an antigen. In a secondary response, there is a rapid increase in IgM production, followed by a switch to IgG production.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 136

questions.text: Image below shows different types of vegetative endocarditis. Which of these images best depicts the vegetations of infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
I - RHD

II - IE

III - NBTE

IV - LSE

II (IE) represents Infective Endocarditis, which is characterized by vegetations on the heart valves. These vegetations are composed of microorganisms (like bacteria) and various components, such as fibrin and platelets. They can vary in size and appearance but are a hallmark feature of infective endocarditis.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, page no 562

questions.text: Nephritic syndrome is characterized by which of the following?
questions.solution:
The main clinical features of nephritic syndrome include the following:

  • Hematuria (red blood cells and red cell casts in urine)
  • Proteinuria (usually subnephrotic range) with or without edema
  • Azotemia
  • Hypertension

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, page no 906

questions.text: Isoelectric point is when:
questions.solution:
At Its Isoelectric pH (pI), an Amino Acid Bears No Net Charge

Zwitterions are one example of an isoelectric species the form of a molecule that has an equal number of positive and negative charges and thus is electrically neutral.

The isoelectric pH, also called the pI, is the pH midway between pKa values for the ionizations on either side of the isoelectric species.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page no 20

choices.text: Facilitated diffusion is saturable, simple diffusion is not
Facilitated diffusion requires ATP, simple diffusion does not
Facilitated diffusion is not chemically specific unlike simple diffusion
Facilitated diffusion is dependent on a concentration gradient, simple diffusion is not

questions.text: Facilitated diffusion can be distinguished from simple diffusion by which of the following statements?
questions.solution:
Facilitated diffusion is saturable, meaning that it can become saturated when all carrier proteins are in use, whereas simple diffusion is not saturable. This is one of the key distinctions between the two types of diffusion.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 52.

questions.text: At which vertebral level does the esophagus end by opening into the stomach?
questions.solution:
Abdominal part of esophagus:

  • The abdominal part of the esophagus is only about 1.25 cm long.
  • It enters the abdomen through the esophageal opening of the diaphragm situated at the level of vertebra T10, slightly to the left of the median plane.
  • It continues with the cardiac end of stomach
  • The esophagus runs downwards and to the left in front of the left crus of the diaphragm and of the inferior surface of the left lobe of the liver, and ends by opening into the cardiac end of the stomach at the level of vertebra T11, about 2.5 cm to the left of the median plane.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 2, 8th Edition, Page No 291, 292

choices.text: Granulomatous bile duct destruction is characteristic on histology
Antibody titres correlate directly with progression of disease
It is associated with increased risk of Hepatocellular carcinoma

questions.text: A 35-year old man complains of hematemesis and yellowish discolouration of urine. On examination, xanthelasmas are observed. He has past history of ulcerative colitis few years ago. On liver biopsy, he is diagnosed with primary biliary cholangitis. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: The role of antimitochondrial antibodies in the pathogenesis of PBC is unclear, as 5% of patients with otherwise typical PBC are antimitochondrial antibody (AMA)-negative. Moreover, antibody titers do not correlate with disease severity or disease progression, and they are not predictive of response to therapy.

Option A: The histologic picture of lymphocytic and/or granulomatous bile duct destruction (florid duct lesion) is highly characteristic of PBC.

Option C: The diagnosis can be established if two of the following are present: elevated alkaline phosphatase for more than 6 months; positive test for antimitochondrial antibodies; and characteristic histologic findings.

Option D: Like many chronic forms of hepatic injury, PBC is associated with an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, page no 857-858

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with an abscess on his left thigh. The lesion is warm, tender, and fluctuant. Purulent material is drained, and a culture of the abscess yields Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following virulence factors is primarily responsible for the ability of Staphylococcus aureus to cause skin and soft tissue infections?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus aureus is a Gram-positive cocci that produces several virulence factors contributing to its pathogenicity. Coagulase is an enzyme produced by Staphylococcus aureus that converts fibrinogen to fibrin, resulting in the formation of a protective fibrin clot around the bacteria. This clot helps the bacteria evade the host immune response and antibiotics, promoting the establishment of abscesses in the skin and soft tissues. Coagulase is a key factor in the pathogenesis of localized Staphylococcus aureus infections, such as skin abscesses. Exfoliative toxin is associated with staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, enterotoxin with food poisoning, and hemolysin with the destruction of red blood cells.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no. 451

questions.text: A 60-year old man has substernal chest pain radiating to his left shoulder. On examination he has tachycardia with low blood pressure. His laboratory work-up shows raised troponin-I and CK-MB levels. He dies 1 day later due to ventricular tachycardia. Gross appearance of his heart stained with triphenyl tetrazolium chloride is shown here. The principle enzyme leading to this cell defect is
questions.solution:
This gross histochemical stain imparts a brick-red color to intact, non-infarcted myocardium with preserved lactate dehydrogenase activity. Because dehydrogenases leak out through the damaged membranes of dead cells, an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, page no 548

choices.text: Mutations in receptor tyrosine kinase RET may be found
Acetylcholinesterase stain is used to identify ganglion cells
The aganglionic segment undergoes progressive dilation

questions.text: A 2-day old infant has not passed meconium even at 48 hours after birth. A single episode of vomiting also occurs. On examination, his abdomen is distended. Following a barium enema study, emergency colectomy is performed. Intraoperative photograph of his rectum and sigmoid colon is shown below. What is not true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Image shows constricted rectum and dilation of the sigmoid colon. In Hirschsprung disease, the normally innervated proximal colon undergoes progressive dilation and may become massively distended (megacolon) as a result of the distal obstruction.

Option D: The aganglionic region may have a grossly normal or contracted appearance.

Option A: Heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase RET account for the majority of familial and approximately 15% of sporadic Hirschsprung disease cases.

Option B: In addition to their characteristic morphology in hematoxylin and eosin-stained sections, ganglion cells can be identified using immunohistochemical stains for acetylcholinesterase.

Option C: The rectum is always affected, but the length of the additional involved segments varies widely. In most cases the abnormality extends to the sigmoid colon, but in severe cases, the entire colon may be involved.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, page no 756

questions.text: Which among the following is an early sign of magnesium toxicity when magnesium sulphate is given in case of pre-eclampsia?
questions.solution:
Knee jerk (patellar reflex) starts diminishing at plasma magnesium concentration of 4mEq/L and disappears at 10 mEq/L, where respiratory paralysis is a potential hazard.

(a) Depression of deep tendon reflexes: This is considered an early sign of magnesium toxicity. Magnesium is a central nervous system depressant, and a decrease in deep tendon reflexes can indicate the need to adjust the dosage or discontinue magnesium sulfate to prevent further toxicity.

(b) Respiratory depression: This is a more severe manifestation of magnesium toxicity. High levels of magnesium can lead to respiratory muscle paralysis, resulting in respiratory depression.

(c) Cardiac arrest: Cardiac arrest is a rare but serious complication of magnesium toxicity. Extremely high levels of magnesium can affect the heart's electrical conduction system, leading to cardiac arrest.

(d) Decreased urine output: While decreased urine output can be associated with various conditions, it is not a specific early sign of magnesium toxicity. Other signs, such as changes in reflexes, typically precede more severe manifestations.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 24th Edition - Page no 737

questions.text: Match the following hypersensitivity disorders with their prototypes
questions.solution:
The correct matching of hypersensitivity disorders with their prototypes is as follows:

(i) Type-I hypersensitivity reaction: (b) Bronchial asthma

(ii) Type-II hypersensitivity reaction: (c) Goodpasture syndrome

(iii) Type-III hypersensitivity reaction: (d) Arthur's reaction

(iv) Type-IV hypersensitivity reaction: (a) Type I Diabetes

So, the correct answer is (B). Here's an explanation for each:

(i) Type-I hypersensitivity reaction involves immediate hypersensitivity and includes conditions like bronchial asthma.

(ii) Type-II hypersensitivity reaction involves cytotoxic reactions and includes conditions like Goodpasture syndrome, where antibodies target and damage specific tissues.

(iii) Type-III hypersensitivity reaction is associated with immune complex deposition, and Arthur's reaction is a hypothetical example of this type of reaction.

(iv) Type-IV hypersensitivity reaction is a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction and includes conditions like Type I Diabetes, which is an autoimmune disease.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, page no 204

questions.text: A 24 year old lady had sore throat for 3 days with fever and headache. On examination she was dehydrated, Her BP was 80/50 mm Hg and on the distal aspect of cuff, small red spots were noted. What could be the most probable etiological agent responsible for causing these symptoms.
questions.solution:
The symptoms described in the question are suggestive of meningococcal meningitis, which is caused by the bacterium Neisseria meningitidis. The rash is characteristic of this infection.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no. 225

questions.text: Which of the following is false about heparin?
questions.solution:
Heparin is an anticoagulant and a glycosaminoglycan, but it does not release hormone-sensitive lipase.

Hormone-sensitive lipase is an enzyme that plays a key role in the regulation of lipid metabolism in the body. It is responsible for breaking down triglycerides stored in fat cells into free fatty acids and glycerol when the body needs energy. Heparin, on the other hand, is primarily used as an anticoagulant. It works by inhibiting the formation of blood clots by enhancing the activity of antithrombin III, which in turn inhibits the action of various coagulation factors, particularly thrombin.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page no 257.

questions.text: Savlon contains which of the following agents:
questions.solution:
Savlon is a brand of antiseptic solutions and creams. It contains the antiseptic agents cetrimide and chlorhexidine. These agents are used to disinfect and clean wounds and skin, helping to prevent infections.

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology 8th Edition, Page no 959-960

questions.text: Identify the disease from Flow Cytogram B given below. Flow cytogram A is from a normal individual.
questions.solution:
(A) Flow cytogram of blood from a normal individual shows that the red cells express two phosphatidylinositol glycan (PIG)-linked membrane proteins, CD55 and CD59, on their surfaces.

(B) Flow cytogram of blood from a patient with PNH shows a population of red cells that is deficient in both CD55 and CD59. As is typical of PNH, a second population of CD55+/ CD59+ red cells that is derived from residual normal hematopoietic stem cells also is present.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, page 648-649

questions.text: Parasite causing pulmonary eosinophilia syndrome-
questions.solution:
Pulmonary eosinophilia is defined as infiltration of eosinophils into the lung compartments constituting airway, interstitium and alveoli.

Various infections, drugs, parasites, autoimmune processes, malignancies, and obstructive lung diseases have been associated with increased eosinophils in lung.

It occurs in Strongyloides, Hook worm infection also.

Confirmed case of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is treated with Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) for 21 days.

DEC is active against both microfilariae and adults. Signs and symptoms respond dramatically with DEC which is the characteristic of TPE.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 273

questions.text: A 28-yr old woman complains of blood in urine. On urine examination, plenty RBCs with red cell casts as well as grade II proteinuria are noted. She develops rapidly progressive renal failure. She has history of fever, cough and skin rash 1 week back. Renal biopsy is advised, histologic image of which is shown in the image. Which of the following markers is most likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Crescentic (Rapidly Progressive) Glomerulonephritis.

The renal manifestations of all forms of crescentic glomerulonephritis include hematuria with red blood cell casts in the urine, moderate proteinuria occasionally reaching the nephrotic range, and variable hypertension and edema.

As seen in image, segmental glomerular necrosis and distinctive crescents adjacent to glomerular segments uninvolved by inflammatory or proliferative changes is the feature most typical of pauci-immune RPGN, in which ANCAs are seen.

Serum analyses for anti-GBM antibodies, antinuclear antibodies, and ANCAs are helpful in the diagnosis of specific subtypes.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, page no 909-910

questions.text: Which amongst the following is the active metabolite of cyclophosphamide
questions.solution:
Cyclophosphamide is well-absorbed orally and is activated to the 4-hydroxy intermediate. Its rate of metabolic activation exhibits significant interpatient variability and increases with successive doses in high-dose regimens but appears to be saturable at concentrations of the parent compound greater than 150 μM. 4-Hydroxycyclophosphamide may be oxidized further by aldehyde oxidase, either in liver or in tumor tissue, to inactive metabolites. 4-Hydroxycyclophosphamide and its tautomer, aldophosphamide, travel in the circulation to tumor cells, where aldophosphamide cleaves spontaneously, generating stoichiometric amounts of phosphoramide mustard and acrolein. Phosphoramide mustard is responsible for antitumor effects, while acrolein causes hemorrhagic cystitis often seen during therapy with cyclophosphamide.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's: The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page 1172

questions.text: Which of the following side chains is least polar?
questions.solution:
Following side chains containing amino acids are polar.

  • Carboxyl
  • Amino
  • Phosphate
  • Hydroxy

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page no 18.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism of invasion and metastasis?
questions.solution:
Option B: MMPs regulate tumor invasion not only by remodeling the basement membrane and interstitial connective tissue, but also by releasing factors that contribute to the malignant behavior of cancers. Benign tumors of the breast, colon, and stomach have little MMP-9 activity, whereas their malignant counterparts overexpress this enzyme.

Option A: In several epithelial tumors including certain adenocarcinomas of the stomach and breast, E-cadherin function is lost due to pathogenic mutations, and in many other epithelial cancers it is hypothesized that E-cadherin expression is silenced, at least transiently, through a process called epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT).

Option C: Loss of adhesion in normal cells leads to induction of apoptosis, but free tumor cells are resistant to this form of cell death (termed anoikis, meaning without a home), in part because of expression of other integrins that mitigate the loss of adhesion to ECM, apparently by transmitting signals that promote cell survival.

Option D: Locomotion is the final step of invasion, propelling tumor cells through the degraded basement membranes and zones of matrix proteolysis. Such movement seems to be stimulated and directed by several types of factors like Tumor cell–derived cytokines including chemokines and growth factors, cleavage products of matrix components (e.g., – collagen, laminin), and stromal cell–derived paracrine factors such as hepatocyte growth factor/scatter factor. 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, page no 307-308

questions.text: Which of the following monoclonal antibody is approved for the treatment of toxin of Clostridium difficile?
questions.solution:
Clostridium difficile diarrhea is a super-infection also called as Pseudomembranous colitis.

  • Most common cause is 3rd generation Cephalosporins.
  • Other causes include Clindamycin followed by Aminopenicillins (Ampicillin and Amoxycillin), and then Fluoroquinolones.
  • DOC for treatment of PMC is oral Vancomycin now.
  • Stool transplant can also be done.
  • MAB against toxin of C.difficile: Bezlotoxumab.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's: The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition - Page 661

questions.text: A 21-yr old girl has irregular menses for past 3 years. She presented to OPD with complaint of recently developed hirsutism, hoarseness of voice and enlarged clitoris. USG findings show right adnexal mass, which is then laparoscopically removed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
These tumors are often functional; they most commonly produce masculinization or defeminization, but a few have estrogenic effects. The peak incidence is in the second and third decades.

These neoplasms may block normal female sexual development in children and may cause defeminization of women, manifest by atrophy of the breasts, amenorrhea, sterility, and loss of hair. The syndrome may progress to striking virilization (hirsutism) associated with male hair distribution, hypertrophy of the clitoris, and voice changes.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, page no 1027-1028

questions.text: Which amongst the following is the most potent statin:
questions.solution:
Pitavastatin This is the latest and dose-to-dose the most potent statin. However, no specific advantage compared to other statins has been demonstrated, and experience with its use is limited.

A ceiling response of 40% LDL-CH reduction with the maximum recommended daily dose of 4 mg is noted. The plasma t½ is 12 hours.

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology 8th Edition, Page no 685

questions.text: A 25-yr old woman complains of dyspnea and cough with expectoration containing chunks of gelatinous material. On X-ray examination, patchy asymmetric opacifications are observed in both lung fields. On electron microscopy, type 2 pneumocytes containing small surfactant lamellae are seen. A light microscopy image of her biopsy is shown below. Auto-antibodies against which of the following may be seen?
questions.solution:
Image shows histopathology of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP), in which the alveoli are filled with a dense, amorphous, protein-lipid granular precipitate, while the alveolar walls are normal.

Autoimmune PAP is caused by autoantibodies that bind and neutralize the function of GM-CSF.

Adult patients, for the most part, present with cough and abundant sputum that often contains chunks of gelatinous material. Progressive dyspnea, cyanosis, and respiratory insufficiency may occur.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, page no 700

questions.text: E coli is classified under Enterobacteriaceae. There are many subspecies of E Coli. One sub species causes hemolytic uremic syndrome. This syndrome is caused by EHEC O157: H7. The culture media used for this organism is?
questions.solution:
EHEC O157: H7 is a sorbitol-negative strain of Escherichia coli. Sorbitol MacConkey media is used to culture this organism, as it does not ferment sorbitol and therefore produces colorless colonies on this medium.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 280

choices.text: Heating to 60 degrees Celsius for 1 hour

questions.text: All of the following methods can be used to kill hepatitis A virus except:
questions.solution:
The hepatitis A virus withstands heating to 60 degrees Celsius for 1 hour, and is not affected by chlorine in doses usually employed for chlorination.

The virus is inactivated by ultraviolet rays (option A) and by boiling for 5 minutes (option B) or autoclaving (option D).

questions.text: Which of the following antihelminthic drug also acts as immunomodulator:
questions.solution:
Levamisole:

Levamisole is an immunomodulator as well: restores depressed T cell function. It was used as a disease modifying drug in rheumatoid arthritis and as an adjunct in malignancies, aphthous ulcers and recurrent herpes, but repeated doses produce severe reactions; not used now.

questions.solution:
Chronaxie refers to the minimum duration for which a stimulus of double the rheobase intensity must be applied to produce a response. It is an index of the excitability of a tissue.

questions.text: What is the most probable portal of entry of Aspergillus -
questions.solution:
Aspergillosis

  • Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common cause of aspergillosis.
  • Aspergillus is a mold with septate branching hyphae.
  • Ability of A. fumigatus to grow at 45'C helps to distinguish it from other species
  • Mode of transmission → Inhalation of Aspergillus spores (Conidia).
  • The commonest human disease caused by aspergillus is otomycosis.
  • Aspergillus infection in neutropenic patient is characterized by hyphal invasion of blood vessels, thrombosis, necrosis and hemorrhagic infarction.
  • Clinical manifestations

1.Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis occurs in patients with preexisting asthma or cystic fibrosis

2.Endobronchial saprophytic pulmonary aspergillosis (Aspergilloma) in a patient with prior chronic lung disease, such as tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, bronchiectasis or histoplasmosis.

3.Invasive aspergillosis develops as an acute pneumonic process with or without dissemination in the immuno-compromized patients (most common among patients with acute leukemia and recipient of tissue transplants.

CT finding -> Halo sign and crescent sign

4.Allergic sinusitis may take three forms:

  1. A fungal ball may form.
  2. Chronic fibrosing granulomatous inflammation transplants.
  3. Allergic fungal sinusitis

5.Aspergillosis in AIDS:

- Most commonly infect lung

- CD4 cell count is <50/μL

- Most common radiologic finding is bilateral diffuse or focal pulmonary infiltrates with a tendency to cavitate.

6.Extrapulmonary:

-Otomycosis -Endophthalmitis

-Keratitis -Endocarditis

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 613

questions.text: Which of the following drug used in irritable bowel syndrome with constipation predominant:
questions.solution:
Lubiprostone- This PG analogue developed recently, represents a new strategy in the treatment of constipation predominant IBS and in idiopathic chronic constipation.

Lubiprostone is an EP4 receptor agonist which activates mucosal Cl¯ channels by stimulating guanylyl-cyclase C. It produces Cl¯ rich intestinal fluid and accelerates colonic transit. Refractoriness to its beneficial effects in chronic constipation does not appear to develop even after prolonged use. It also delays gastric emptying. Only a small fraction of the administered dose is absorbed.

The most common side effect is nausea; others are dyspepsia and diarrhoea.

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology 8th Edition, Page no 724

questions.text: A man on return from Russia complains of pain in abdomen, jaundice, with increased alkaline phosphatase and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. USG shows blockage in the biliary tree. What could be the cause -
questions.solution:
Clonorchis sinesis:

  • Clonorchis sinensis is a trematode. It is also known as liver fluke.
  • Man is definitive host for Clonorchis and snail is the secondary host.
  • Clonorchis sinensis is caused by ingestion of metacercaria in inadequately cooked freshwater fish.
  • The organisms excyst in the duodenum.
  • The larva travel through the ampulla of Vater and mature into adult worms in bile canaliculi.
  • The adult worms release small operculated eggs which pass with bile into the intestines and are voided with stools.

Most of the infections are asymptomatic because of the low worm burden.

Chronic infection or repeated infection is associated with manifestations such as:

-Cholangitis

-Cholangiohepatitis

-Biliary obstruction (Biliary obstruction causes increase in alkaline phosphatase).

Also know

Clonorchis sinensis infection is associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 527

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding propaganda is false?
questions.solution:
Propaganda prevents or discourages thinking by using ready-made slogans, while education makes people think for themselves.

Propaganda appeals to emotion while education appeals to reason (option A).

Propaganda stimulates primitive desires while education disciplines primitive desires. (option B).

Propaganda is information- centered (no change of attitude or behaviour is designed) while education is behaviour- centered (aims at developing favourable attitudes, habits and skills).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page no 922

questions.text: Find the compliance of the lung in ml/cm H2O when Transpulmonary pressure was changed to 8 cmH2O of a man who inspired 1000 ml of air from a spirometer.
questions.solution:
Compliance is defined as the change in volume per unit change in Transpulmonary pressure. The formula for compliance(C) is: Change in lung volume (ΔV)/Change in Transpulmonary pressure(ΔP). In this case, ΔP is 8 cm H2O and the volume change(ΔV) is 1000 ml. Therefore, the compliance (C) is (ΔV/ΔP) = 1000/8 = 125 ml/cm H2O.

Reference: Indu Khurana Medical Physiology, 2nd edition, Page no. 282.

questions.text: Oculus Dexter refers to
questions.solution:
The term "Oculus Dexter" refers to the right eye. In medical terminology, "Oculus" means "eye", and "Dexter" means "right". Similarly, "Oculus Sinister" refers to the left eye, with "Sinister" meaning "left". So, the correct answer is (B) Right eye.

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana 6th edition, Page no 3

questions.text: Secretions for olfactory epithelium is provided by?
questions.solution:
Bowman's gland, also known as the olfactory gland, is located within the olfactory epithelium in the nasal cavity. It secretes a mucus-like substance that helps trap and dissolve odorants in the inhaled air. This mucus serves to moisten and protect the delicate sensory cells of the olfactory epithelium, ensuring that they can function properly by detecting and transmitting smell signals to the brain.

The other options (b) Jobson's gland, (c) Jacobson's organ, and (d) Stenson's gland are not directly associated with the secretions for the olfactory epithelium. Jacobson's organ, for example, is involved in the detection of pheromones in some animals, but it is not related to the olfactory gland in humans.

Reference: Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery, 7th edition, Page no 1328

choices.text: All have the same incubation period

questions.text: Which form of plague has the shortest incubation period?
questions.solution:
Incubation period:

(a) bubonic plague: 2 to 7 days

(b) septicemic plague: 2 to 7 days

(c) pneumonic plague: 1 to 3 days

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page no 322

questions.text: A 56 year old male patient Raju was prescribed diuretic medicine for hypertension. Later he presented with difficulty in hearing and diagnosed with having moderate deafness. Which of the following drug is responsible for this adverse effect:
questions.solution:
Loop diuretics can cause ototoxicity that manifests as tinnitus, hearing impairment, deafness, vertigo, and a sense of fullness in the ears. Hearing impairment and deafness are usually, but not always, reversible. Ototoxicity occurs most frequently with rapid intravenous administration and least frequently with oral administration. To avoid ototoxicity, the rate of furosemide infusions should not exceed 4 mg/min. Ethacrynic acid appears to induce ototoxicity more often than do other loop diuretics and should be reserved for use only in patients who cannot tolerate other loop diuretics

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's: The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page 454

choices.text: Portal vein, hepatic artery, hepatic duct
Portal vein, hepatic duct, hepatic artery
Hepatic duct, hepatic artery, portal vein
Hepatic duct, portal vein, hepatic artery

questions.text: Which is correct arrangement of structures at porta hepatic from before backwards?
questions.solution:
• The right and left hepatic ducts emerge at the porta hepatis from the right and left lobes of the liver.
  • The arrangement of structures at the porta hepatis from behind forwards is
    • Branches of the portal vein

questions.text: Common organism implicated in cystic fibrosis are all except
questions.solution:
The most common organism implicated in cystic fibrosis - mucoid strain of pseudomonas followed by Burkholderia cepacia, H influenza and S aureus

Other gram-negative rods recovered form Cystic fibrosis sputum include Alcaligenes xylosoxidans, B gladioli, occasionally proteus, E coli and Klebsiella, Aspergillus fumigates and non-tuberculous mycobacteria.

questions.text: On examining medical case files from the 1950s, you come across the case of a 2 year old child who suffered from a disease characterized by fever with rash. The diagnosis is mentioned as chicken-pox. All of the following features would have favoured the diagnosis of chicken-pox over smallpox except:
questions.solution:
Chicken-pox is characterized by a centripetal (lesions concentrated on the trunk and fewer on the extremities) rash, while smallpox is characterized by a centrifugal (lesions concentrated on the extremities with fewer lesions on the trunk) rash.

Smallpox has severe prodromal symptoms (fever, headache, backache, vomiting and sometimes convulsions), while chickenpox has milder prodromal symptoms (option A).

The rash in chickenpox typically spares the palms and soles, while they are frequently involved in smallpox (option C).

The rash in chickenpox is pleomorphic (different stages of the rash evident at one given time), while in smallpox it is monomorphic (only one stage of rash may be seen at one time) (option D).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page no 158

choices.text: Grade 1 - Simultaneous Macular Perception, Grade 2 - Fusion, Grade 3 - Stereopsis
Grade - 1 Fusion, Grade - 2 Simultaneous Macular Perception, Grade - 3 Stereopsis
Grade - 1 Simultaneous Macular Perception, Grade - 2 Stereopsis, Grade - 3 Fusion
Grade - 1 Fusion, Grade - 2 Stereopsis, Grade - 3 Simultaneous Macular Perception

questions.text: Identify correct order of Grades of Binocular Vision
questions.solution:
Grade - 1: Simultaneous Macular Perception - This is the first level of binocular vision where both eyes work together to perceive a single image. It involves the brain's ability to combine the slightly different images received from each eye into one coherent image.

Grade - 2: Fusion - Fusion is the second level of binocular vision. It refers to the ability of the brain to combine the images from each eye into a single image while maintaining binocular single vision. Fusion ensures that the images are aligned and overlap correctly.

Grade - 3: Stereopsis - Stereopsis is the highest level of binocular vision. It represents the ability to perceive depth and three-dimensional relationships between objects. Stereopsis relies on the brain's ability to process the slight disparities between the images received from each eye to create the perception of depth.

So, the correct order is as presented in option (A).

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 714, 715

questions.text: Under the National Vector-Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP), which category of states are in the elimination phase?
questions.solution:
Category 0 (Prevention of re-establishment phase): States/UTs with zero indigenous cases of malaria

Category 1 (Elimination phase): States/UTs with API less than one. and all their districts reporting API < 1

Category 2 (Pre-elimination phase): States/UTs with API < 1, but some of their districts reporting API > 1

Category 3 (Intensified control phase): States UTs with API > 1

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page no 447

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with optic disc swelling?
questions.solution:
Retinal detachment is a condition in which the retina separates from the underlying tissues, typically causing peripheral vision loss. It is not typically associated with optic disc swelling, which is a common finding in papilledema, optic neuritis, and glaucoma. 

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 753

questions.text: Arsenic is useful in the treatment of which of the following tumor:
questions.solution:
AS2O3 promote the differentiation of APL cells and promote apoptosis by upregulating the genes involved in apoptosis. It is used for the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia.

Arsenic trioxide Arsenic has been a traditional poison for ages.

Lately therapeutic value of small doses of arsenic trioxide in APL has been recognized. It probably acts by enhancing reactive oxygen free radical generation in APL cells. Arsenic trioxide is also being included in the 1st line therapy of APL along with tretinoin + an anthracycline, particularly in high risk cases and in those who have initial WBC count of > 10,000/μL. With such triple therapy ~ 90% APL patients have remained in long-term remission

Reference: K.D Tripathi - Essentials of medical pharmacology 8th Edition, Page no 928

questions.text: A nucleic acid was isolated from sample and analysis about nucleotide base were done. And in analysis technician found that nucleic acid contains 32% adenine, 18% guanine, 17% cytosine and 33% thymine. The nucleic acid must be:
questions.solution:
The above nucleic acid is obeying Chargaff's rule as the number of Purines (32 + 18) = No of Pyrimidines (17 + 33).

Together with x-ray diffraction data from the DNA molecule generated by Franklin, and the observation of Chargaff that in DNA molecules the concentration of deoxyadenosine (A) nucleotides equals that of thymidine (T) nucleotides (A = T), while the concentration of deoxyguanosine (G) nucleotides equals that of deoxycytidine (C) nucleotides (G = C), led Watson, Crick, and Wilkins to propose in the early 1950s a model of a double-stranded DNA molecule.

Double stranded RNA is not the answer as it does not contain Thymine.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page no 360.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever and a rash. Laboratory tests reveal thrombocytopenia, and a bone marrow biopsy shows hypocellular marrow. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this case is aplastic anemia. Aplastic anemia is characterized by a hypocellular marrow, which means that the bone marrow has reduced cellularity, leading to a decrease in the production of all blood cells, including platelets (thrombocytopenia). Fever and rash can also be seen in some cases of aplastic anemia. Treatment options for aplastic anemia include supportive care, immunosuppressive therapy, and bone marrow transplant.

Reference: Guyton and Hall, Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th edition, Pg. 439-447.

choices.text: 20 mg elemental iron and 100 mcg folic acid, bi-weekly
45 mg elemental iron and 400 mcg folic acid, weekly
45 mg elemental iron and 400 mcg folic acid, bi-weekly

questions.text: According to Anemia Mukt Bharat programme of Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation, how much iron and folic should be supplemented and at what frequency to a 7 year old girl:
questions.solution:
45 mg elemental iron and 400 mcg folic acid, weekly

Iron is an essential mineral that helps to carry oxygen throughout the body. Folic acid is a B vitamin that is important for the production of red blood cells.

Children between the ages of 4 and 8 need 10 milligrams of iron per day. However, iron supplements are typically dosed in terms of elemental iron, which is the amount of iron that is actually absorbed by the body.

The Anemia Mukt Bharat programme recommends that 7-year-old girls receive a weekly supplement of 45 mg elemental iron, which is equivalent to 4.5 times the recommended daily intake. This is because iron absorption is not very efficient, and some of the iron that is consumed is lost in stool.

Folic acid is also important for children, and the recommended daily intake for children between the ages of 4 and 8 is 400 mcg. The Anemia Mukt Bharat programme recommends that 7-year-old girls receive a weekly supplement of 400 mcg folic acid, which is equal to the recommended daily intake.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page no 1026

choices.text: Lacrimal gland → lacrimal sac → nasolacrimal duct → inferior meatus
Lacrimal sac → lacrimal gland → nasolacrimal duct → inferior meatus
Lacrimal gland → nasolacrimal duct → lacrimal sac → inferior meatus
Nasolacrimal duct → lacrimal sac → lacrimal gland → inferior meatus

questions.text: Which is the correct order of the lacrimal pathway?
questions.solution:
Lacrimal gland → lacrimal sac → nasolacrimal duct → inferior meatus

In this pathway, tears are produced by the lacrimal gland, then flow into the lacrimal sac, followed by the nasolacrimal duct, and finally, they drain into the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity. This pathway allows tears to be produced and drained effectively, helping to keep the eye moist and functioning properly.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 100

questions.solution:
Several standardized and practical psychophysical tests have been developed over the last several years, including a number of brief self-administered tests ranging from the three-item Pocket Smell TestTM to the 40-item University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT). 27 The UPSIT is commercially known as the Smell Identification TestTM and is the most widely used olfactory test, having been administered to an estimated 400,000 patients since its development

questions.text: All are true about the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) in comparison to the oral polio vaccine (OPV) except:
questions.solution:
IPV is more difficult to manufacture.

IPV does not require stringent conditions during storage and transportation, while OPV has to be stored and transported at sub-zero temperatures, unless stabilized (option B).

IPV induces circulating antibody, but no local (intestinal) immunity; while immunity with OPV is both humoral and intestinal (option C).

The virus content in IPV is 10,000 times more than OPV, hence it is costlier (option D).

questions.text: Which of the following artery gives ascending branch running in intertubercular sulcus?
questions.solution:
Anterior circumflex humeral artery:

  • It is a small branch arising from the third part of the axillary artery, at the lower border of the subscapularis.
  • It passes laterally in front of the intertubercular sulcus of the humerus, and anastomoses with the posterior circumflex humeral artery, to form an arterial circle round the surgical neck of the humerus.
  • It gives off an ascending branch which runs in the intertubercular sulcus, and supplies the head of the humerus and shoulder joint

questions.text: What is the direction of the fibres of external intercostal muscle?
questions.solution:
External Intercostal Muscle:

  • The external intercostal muscle:
    • Extends from the tubercle of the rib posteriorly to the costochondral junction anteriorly.
    • Between the costochondral junction and the sternum, it is replaced by the external or anterior intercostal membrane.
    • The posterior end of the muscle is continuous with the posterior fibres of the superior costotransverse ligament.
  • The fibres of the external intercostal muscle run downwards, forwards and medially in anterior part of intercostal spaces.
  • Nerve supply: All intercostal muscles are supplied by the intercostal nerves of the spaces in which they lie.
  • Action: It elevates the ribs during inspiration.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 1, 8th Edition, Page No 240, 241, 242

questions.text: A young woman was admitted to the hospital after experiencing nausea and vomiting for about 3 days followed by muscle weakness and neurologic symptoms, including dysphagia. She indicated she had eaten at a restaurant before the symptoms began. Laboratory tests were positive for Clostridium botulinum. What is the Mechanism of Action of Botulinum toxin?
questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin acts by preventing the release of neurotransmitters in the central nervous system and at the neuromuscular junction. Symptoms can include ptosis (drooping eyelid), diplopia (double vision), dysarthria (slurred speech), dysphonia (difficulty speaking), and dysphagia (difficulty swallowing).

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Pg. 99-120

questions.text: Vertebral level of origin of internal carotid artery
questions.solution:
The internal carotid artery:

  • It is one of the two terminal branches of the common carotid artery.
  • It begins at the level of the upper border of the thyroid cartilage.
  • Opposite to the disc between the third and fourth cervical vertebrae.
  • It ends inside the cranial cavity by supplying the brain.
  • This is the principal artery of the brain and the eye.
  • It also supplies the related bones and meninges.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 3, 8th Edition, Page No - 166

questions.text: Calcium bound to the troponin-tropomyosin complex induces a conformational change in the thin filament, allowing myosin heads to cross-bridge with thin filament actin. Which of the following triggers detachment of the myosin head from the actin filament?
questions.solution:
The detachment of the myosin head from the actin filament occurs when ATP binds to the myosin head. This binding causes myosin to release actin, allowing actin and myosin to detach from each other.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents with a history of three episodes of meningitis associated with episodes of right sided acute suppurative otitis media. She was born with a right-sided unilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss. You suspect that she has?
questions.solution:
She had a severe Mondini malformation with dehiscence of the medial wall of the vestibule with a large cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) connection between the internal auditory canal and the vestibule. She also had an incomplete stapes footplate allowing the CSF to bulge a CSF containing thin mucosal cyst filling the oval window niche.

questions.text: A patient presented with ataxia when the eyes are closed and not able to walk in a straight line. Heel-shin test was positive. What is the diagnosis, and which tract is involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The symptoms described, including ataxia when the eyes are closed and a positive heel-shin test, are characteristic of cerebellar ataxia. The dorsal spinocerebellar tract is primarily involved in unconscious proprioception, and when compromised, it can lead to difficulty walking in a straight line when the eyes are closed.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for gonococcal conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Gonococcal conjunctivitis requires maximum systemic antibiotic therapy. Topical therapy may be added but is of secondary importance. Ocular irrigation may be of assistance in removing infectious agents from the ocular surface. Because of the increasing problem of penicillin resistant strains of gonococcus ceftriaxone administered intramuscularly, 1 gram daily for 5 consecutive days, is now the drug of choice. If the organism is highly sensitive to penicillin and the patient does not have a history of penicillin allergy, penicillin becomes the antibiotic of first choice.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page no 168

questions.text: All of the followings are tributaries of cavernous sinus, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Tributaries or incoming channels of cavernous sinus:

  • From the orbit
    • The superior ophthalmic vein
    • A branch of the inferior ophthalmic vein or sometimes the vein itself
    • The central vein of the retina may drain either into the superior ophthalmic vein or into the cavernous sinus
  • From the brain
    • Superficial middle cerebral vein
    • Inferior cerebral veins from the temporal lobe
  • From the meninges
    • Sphenoparietal sinus
    • The frontal trunk of the middle meningeal vein may drain either into the pterygoid plexus through the foramen ovale or into the sphenoparietal or cavernous sinus

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 3, 8th Edition, Page No - 217
